      have hS_plus_neq_minus : (S p 1 : ℤ) ≠ S_int p (-1) := by
        sorry
      -- Assume that $\left(x_{n}\right)$ and $\left(y_{n}\right)$ are two $p$-sequences with $S_{p}\left(x_{0}\right)>S_{p}\left(y_{0}\right)$ but $x_{0} < y_{0}$.
      -- The first condition yields that  $$ x_{M q+r}-y_{M q+r}=\left(x_{r}-y_{r}\right)+M\left(S_{p}\left(x_{0}\right)-S_{p}\left(y_{0}\right)\right) \geqslant\left(x_{r}-y_{r}\right)+M $$  for all nonnegative integers $M$ and every $r=0,1, \ldots, q-1$.
      have hxy : ∀ x0 y0 : ℕ, S p x0 > S p y0 -> x0 < y0 ->
        ∀ M r, r < q -> (p_seq p x0 (M * q + r) : ℤ) - (p_seq p y0 (M * q + r) : ℤ) ≥ (p_seq p x0 r : ℤ) - (p_seq p y0 r : ℤ) + M := by
        sorry
      -- Thus, we have $x_{n}>y_{n}$ for every sufficiently large n
      have hxy' : ∀ x0 y0 : ℕ, S p x0 > S p y0 -> x0 < y0 ->
        ∃ n0, ∀ n, n ≥ n0 -> p_seq p x0 n > p_seq p y0 n := by
        -- namely every $n \geqslant q+q \cdot \max \left\{y_{r}-x_{r}: r=0,1, \ldots, q-1\right\}$.

        sorry
      -- Now, since $x_{0} < y_{0}$, there exists the largest $n_{0}$ with $x_{n_{0}}< y_{n_{0}}$,
      have hxy'' : ∀ x0 y0 : ℕ, S p x0 > S p y0 -> x0 < y0 ->
        ∃ n0, p_seq p x0 n0 < p_seq p y0 n0 ∧ ∀ n, n ≥ n0 -> p_seq p x0 n > p_seq p y0 n := by
        sorry
      -- We can find $p$-sequences $\left(x_{n}\right)$ and $\left(y_{n}\right)$ satisfying the two conditions.
      have hxy''' : ∃ x0 y0 : ℕ, S p x0 > S p y0 ∧ x0 < y0 := by
        -- Recall that $S_{p}^{+} \neq S_{p}^{-}$.
        by_cases S p 1 > S_int p (-1)
        · -- Now, if $S_{p}^{+}>S_{p}^{-}$, then we can put $x_{0}=1$ and $y_{0}=p-1$.
          use 1, p - 1
          sorry
        · -- Otherwise, if $S_{p}^{+} < S_{p}^{-}$, then we put $x_{0}=p-1$ and $y_{0}=p+1$.
          use p - 1, p + 1
          sorry
      -- Applying the fact we derived
      rcases hxy''' with ⟨x0, y0, hxy''', hxy''''⟩
      specialize hxy'' x0 y0 hxy''' hxy''''
      rcases hxy'' with ⟨n0, hxy''⟩
      -- In this case the $p$-sequences $a_{n}=x_{n+n_{0}}$ and $b_{n}=y_{n+n_{0}}$ possess the desired property
      use (fun n => p_seq p x0 (n + n0)), (fun n => p_seq p y0 (n + n0))
      sorry
    -- Notice that the numbers of the form $2^{q}-1$ are pairwise coprime (since $\operatorname{gcd}\left(2^{q}-1,2^{r}-1\right)=2^{\operatorname{gcd}(q, r)}-1=1$ for any two distinct primes $q$ and $r$ ),
    have hqr : ∀ q r : ℕ, q ≠ r -> q > 3 -> Nat.Prime q -> r > 3 -> Nat.Prime r -> Nat.gcd (2 ^ q - 1) (2 ^ r - 1) = 1 := by
      sorry
    -- thus there exist infinitely many such primes $p$.
    sorry

soln_description:
I. solution. We verify the correctness of the statement by providing an "algorithm" for constructing such an $n$-digit number.

Let's look at the first few solutions:

$$
\begin{array}{rlrlrl}
n=1 & \longrightarrow & 2 & =2 \cdot 1 \\
n=2 & \longrightarrow & 12 & =2^{2} \cdot 3 \\
n=3 & \longrightarrow & 112 & =2^{3} \cdot 14 \\
n=4 & \longrightarrow & 2112 & =2^{4} \cdot 132 \\
n & =5 & \longrightarrow & 22112 & =2^{5} \cdot 691 \\
n & =6 & \longrightarrow & 122112 & =2^{6} \cdot 1908
\end{array}
$$

The following pattern can be observed: if the result of the division by $2^n$ is an odd number, then a 1 is placed in front of the previous number; if it is an even number, then a 2 is placed in front.

We will prove that if we continue to follow this procedure, the resulting $(n+1)$-digit number will always be divisible by $2^{n+1}$.

For $n \geq 6$, the previously obtained $n$-digit number, when divided by $2^n$, will either be odd or even.

Case I: An odd number is obtained. In this case, write a 1 in front of the number. The new number $A$ is of the form $\left(10^{n}+n\right.$-digit number), i.e.,

$$
A=2^{n} \cdot 5^{n}+2^{n}(2 l+1)=2^{n}\left(5^{n}+2 l+1\right)
$$

Since $5^{n}+2 l+1$ is an even number, $2^{n+1} \mid A$ holds.

Case II: An even number is obtained. In this case, write a 2 in front of the number. The new number $B$ is of the form $\left(2 \cdot 10^{n}+n\right.$-digit number):

$$
B=2 \cdot 2^{n} \cdot 5^{n}+2^{n} \cdot 2 k=2^{n}\left(2 \cdot 5^{n}+2 k\right)
$$

Since $2 \cdot 5^{n}+2 k$ is an even number, $2^{n+1} \mid B$ holds.

We have provided a procedure that can construct a $2^n$-divisible $n$-digit number, whose digits consist only of 1s and 2s, for every positive integer $n$.

II. solution. There are $2^n$ $n$-digit numbers that consist only of 1s and 2s (since we can choose from two numbers for each place value).

When all such $n$-digit numbers are divided by $2^n$, we can get at most $2^n$ different remainders (specifically: $0, 1, 2, \ldots, 2^n-1$). We will prove that every such $n$-digit number gives a different remainder when divided by $2^n$.

Indirectly, assume that there are two different $n$-digit numbers consisting only of 1s and 2s that give the same remainder when divided by $2^n$. Thus, the difference between these two numbers (subtracting the smaller from the larger) will be divisible by $2^n$.

This difference can be at most an $n$-digit number, whose first non-zero digit (starting from the units place and moving to the larger values) is either 1 (due to $2-1$) or 9 (due to $1-2$). Thus, this difference number will be of the form $A \cdot 10^k$, where $A$ is an odd natural number, and $k$ is the number of zeros from the units place to the first 1 or 9.

Since the difference is at most an $n$-digit number, based on the above, it can end with at most $(n-1)$ zeros, i.e., the difference is at most divisible by $2^{n-1}$ (since $10^{n-1}=2^{n-1} \cdot 5^{n-1}$). We have reached a contradiction, so there are no two different $n$-digit numbers consisting only of 1s and 2s that give the same remainder when divided by $2^n$. Therefore, every remainder is different.

Considering that there are exactly $2^n$ such $n$-digit numbers, we have exactly $2^n$ different remainders, i.e., there is (exactly one) $n$-digit number that consists only of 1s and 2s and whose remainder when divided by $2^n$ is 0—and this is what we wanted to prove.
informal_statement: Show that for any natural number $n$, there exists an $n$-digit number divisible by $2^{n}$, consisting exclusively of the digits 1 and 2.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Show that for any natural number $n$, there exists an $n$-digit number divisible by $2^{n}$, consisting exclusively of the digits 1 and 2. -/
theorem number_theory_207903 (n : ℕ) :
    ∃ m, (Nat.digits 10 m).length = n ∧ 2^n ∣ m ∧
      (∀ d ∈ (Nat.digits 10 m), d = 1 ∨ d = 2) := by

informal_statement:
Let $A,B\in \mathcal{M}_n(\mathbb{R})$ such that $B^2=I_n$ and $A^2=AB+I_n$. Prove that:

\[\det A\le \left(\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\right)^n\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Matrix Real

/- Let $A,B\in \mathcal{M}_n(\mathbb{R})$ such that $B^2=I_n$ and $A^2=AB+I_n$. Prove that:

\[\det A\le \left(\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\right)^n\] -/
theorem inequalities_86748 {n : ℕ} (A B : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℝ)
    (hB : B ^ 2 = 1) (hA : A ^ 2 = A * B + 1) :
    A.det ≤ ((1 + sqrt 5) / 2) ^ n := by

informal_statement: 25 students average 84 on a test. Another group of 20 students averages 66. Find the overall average.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 25 students average 84 on a test. Another group of 20 students averages 66. Find the overall average. -/
theorem algebra_18791 (count₁ score₁ count₂ score₂ : ℕ)
    (hc₁ : count₁ = 25) (hc₂ : count₂ = 20)
    (hs₁ : score₁ = 84) (hs₂ : score₂ = 66):
    (score₁ * count₁ + score₂ * count₂) / (count₁ + count₂) = (76 : ℝ) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- 25 students average 84 on a test. Another group of 20 students averages 66. Find the overall average. -/
theorem algebra_18791 (count₁ score₁ count₂ score₂ : ℕ)
    (hc₁ : count₁ = 25) (hc₂ : count₂ = 20)
    (hs₁ : score₁ = 84) (hs₂ : score₂ = 66):
    (score₁ * count₁ + score₂ * count₂) / (count₁ + count₂) = (76 : ℝ) := by 
  subst_vars
  norm_num

informal_statement: Let \(a,b,c\) be positive real numbers such that \(\dfrac{ab}{1+bc}+\dfrac{bc}{1+ca}+\dfrac{ca}{1+ab}=1\). Prove that $$\dfrac{1}{a^3}+\dfrac{1}{b^3}+\dfrac{1}{c^3} \ge 6\sqrt{2}$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let \(a,b,c\) be positive real numbers such that \(\dfrac{ab}{1+bc}+\dfrac{bc}{1+ca}+\dfrac{ca}{1+ab}=1\). Prove that $$\dfrac{1}{a^3}+\dfrac{1}{b^3}+\dfrac{1}{c^3} \ge 6\sqrt{2}$$ -/
theorem inequalities_43536 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a * b / (1 + b * c) + b * c / (1 + c * a) + c * a / (1 + a * b) = 1) :
    6 * Real.sqrt 2 ≤ 1 / a ^ 3 + 1 / b ^ 3 + 1 / c ^ 3 := by

informal_statement:
If $a,b,c$ satisfy the system of equations  \begin{align*}b + c &= 12-3a \\
a+c &= -14 - 3b \\
a+b &= 7 - 3c,
\end{align*} what is $2a + 2b + 2c$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $a,b,c$ satisfy the system of equations  \begin{align*}b + c &= 12-3a \\
a+c &= -14 - 3b \\
a+b &= 7 - 3c,
\end{align*} what is $2a + 2b + 2c$? -/
theorem algebra_11817 {a b c : ℝ} (h₀ : b + c = 12 - 3 * a) (h₁ : a + c = -14 - 3 * b)
    (h₂ : a + b = 7 - 3 * c) : 2 * a + 2 * b + 2 * c = 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- If $a,b,c$ satisfy the system of equations  \begin{align*}b + c &= 12-3a \\
a+c &= -14 - 3b \\
a+b &= 7 - 3c,
\end{align*} what is $2a + 2b + 2c$? -/
theorem algebra_11817 {a b c : ℝ} (h₀ : b + c = 12 - 3 * a) (h₁ : a + c = -14 - 3 * b)
    (h₂ : a + b = 7 - 3 * c) : 2 * a + 2 * b + 2 * c = 2 := by
  linarith

informal_statement: What is the least integer whose square is 48 more than its double?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- What is the least integer whose square is 48 more than its double? -/
theorem algebra_13551 : IsLeast {n : ℤ | n^2 = 2 * n + 48} (-6) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_13551 : IsLeast {n : ℤ | n^2 = 2 * n + 48} (-6) := by
  constructor
  · -- Show that -6 is in the set
    show (-6 : ℤ) ^ 2 = 2 * (-6) + 48
    norm_num
  · -- Show that -6 is the least in the set
    intro n hn
    have h : n ^ 2 = 2 * n + 48 := by
      simpa using hn
    have h1 : n ^ 2 - 2 * n - 48 = 0 := by linarith
    have h2 : (n - 8) * (n + 6) = 0 := by 
      nlinarith [h1]
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h2) with h3 h4
    · -- Case where n - 8 = 0, so n = 8
      have h5 : n = 8 := by
        linarith
      linarith
    · -- Case where n + 6 = 0, so n = -6
      have h5 : n = -6 := by
        linarith
      linarith

soln_description:
1. **Assume the roots of \( f(x) = x^3 + ax^2 + bx + c \) are \( \alpha, \beta, \gamma \).**
   By Vieta's formulas, we have:
   \[
   \alpha + \beta + \gamma = -a,
   \]
   \[
   \alpha\beta + \beta\gamma + \gamma\alpha = b,
   \]
   \[
   \alpha\beta\gamma = -c.
   \]

2. **Given \( f(1) = 0 \), we substitute \( x = 1 \) into \( f(x) \):**
   \[
   1^3 + a \cdot 1^2 + b \cdot 1 + c = 0 \implies 1 + a + b + c = 0 \implies a + b + c = -1.
   \]

3. **Assume the roots of \( g(x) = x^3 + bx^2 + cx + a \) are \( \alpha^2, \beta^2, \gamma^2 \).**
   By Vieta's formulas for \( g(x) \), we have:
   \[
   \alpha^2 + \beta^2 + \gamma^2 = -b,
   \]
   \[
   \alpha^2\beta^2 + \beta^2\gamma^2 + \gamma^2\alpha^2 = c,
   \]
   \[
   \alpha^2\beta^2\gamma^2 = -a.
   \]

4. **Using the identity for the sum of squares, we have:**
   \[
   \alpha^2 + \beta^2 + \gamma^2 = (\alpha + \beta + \gamma)^2 - 2(\alpha\beta + \beta\gamma + \gamma\alpha).
   \]
   Substituting the values from Vieta's formulas:
   \[
   \alpha^2 + \beta^2 + \gamma^2 = (-a)^2 - 2b = a^2 - 2b.
   \]
   Given \( \alpha^2 + \beta^2 + \gamma^2 = -b \), we equate:
   \[
   a^2 - 2b = -b \implies a^2 - b = 0 \implies b = a^2.
   \]

5. **Using the identity for the product of squares, we have:**
   \[
   \alpha^2\beta^2\gamma^2 = (\alpha\beta\gamma)^2.
   \]
   Substituting the value from Vieta's formulas:
   \[
   \alpha^2\beta^2\gamma^2 = (-c)^2 = c^2.
   \]
   Given \( \alpha^2\beta^2\gamma^2 = -a \), we equate:
   \[
   c^2 = -a.
   \]

6. **Using the identity for the sum of products of squares, we have:**
   \[
   \alpha^2\beta^2 + \beta^2\gamma^2 + \gamma^2\alpha^2 = (\alpha\beta + \beta\gamma + \gamma\alpha)^2 - 2\alpha\beta\gamma(\alpha + \beta + \gamma).
   \]
   Substituting the values from Vieta's formulas:
   \[
   \alpha^2\beta^2 + \beta^2\gamma^2 + \gamma^2\alpha^2 = b^2 - 2c(-a) = b^2 + 2ac.
   \]
   Given \( \alpha^2\beta^2 + \beta^2\gamma^2 + \gamma^2\alpha^2 = c \), we equate:
   \[
   b^2 + 2ac = c.
   \]

7. **We now have the system of equations:**
   \[
   a + b + c = -1,
   \]
   \[
   b = a^2,
   \]
   \[
   c^2 = -a,
   \]
   \[
   b^2 + 2ac = c.
   \]

8. **Substitute \( b = a^2 \) into the first equation:**
   \[
   a + a^2 + c = -1 \implies c = -1 - a - a^2.
   \]

9. **Substitute \( c = -1 - a - a^2 \) into \( c^2 = -a \):**
   \[
   (-1 - a - a^2)^2 = -a.
   \]
   Expanding and simplifying:
   \[
   1 + 2a + a^2 + a^4 + 2a^3 + a^2 = -a \implies a^4 + 2a^3 + 2a^2 + 3a + 1 = 0.
   \]

10. **Solve the polynomial equation \( a^4 + 2a^3 + 2a^2 + 3a + 1 = 0 \):**
    By trial and error or using the Rational Root Theorem, we find that \( a = -1 \) is a root.

11. **Substitute \( a = -1 \) back into the equations:**
    \[
    b = a^2 = (-1)^2 = 1,
    \]
    \[
    c = -1 - a - a^2 = -1 - (-1) - 1 = -1.
    \]

12. **Verify the solution:**
    \[
    a + b + c = -1 + 1 - 1 = -1,
    \]
    \[
    c^2 = (-1)^2 = 1 = -a,
    \]
    \[
    b^2 + 2ac = 1^2 + 2(-1)(-1) = 1 + 2 = 3 \neq c.
    \]
    There seems to be an inconsistency. Re-evaluate the polynomial equation and verify the roots.

13. **Re-evaluate the polynomial equation \( a^4 + 2a^3 + 2a^2 + 3a + 1 = 0 \):**
    By factoring or using numerical methods, we find that \( a = -1 \) is indeed a root, but we need to verify the consistency of all equations.

14. **Final verification:**
    \[
    a = -1, b = 1, c = -1.
    \]
    \[
    a^{2013} + b^{2013} + c^{2013} = (-1)^{2013} + 1^{2013} + (-1)^{2013} = -1 + 1 - 1 = -1.
    \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{-1}\).
informal_statement:
Let $f(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ and $g(x)=x^3+bx^2+cx+a$, where $a,b,c$ are integers with $c\not=0$. Suppose that the following conditions hold:

[list=a][*]$f(1)=0$,
[*]the roots of $g(x)=0$ are the squares of the roots of $f(x)=0$.[/list]

Find the value of $a^{2013}+b^{2013}+c^{2013}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $f(x)=x^3+ax^2+bx+c$ and $g(x)=x^3+bx^2+cx+a$, where $a,b,c$ are integers with $c\not=0$. Suppose that the following conditions hold:

[list=a][*]$f(1)=0$,
[*]the roots of $g(x)=0$ are the squares of the roots of $f(x)=0$.[/list]

Find the value of $a^{2013}+b^{2013}+c^{2013}$. -/
theorem algebra_55981 {a b c : ℤ} (ha : c ≠ 0) (f g : ℂ → ℂ)
    (hf : f = fun (x : ℂ) => x ^ 3 + a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c)
    (hg : g = fun (x : ℂ) => x ^ 3 + b * x ^ 2 + c * x + a)
    (h1 : f 1 = 0) (h2 : {x : ℤ | g x = 0} = {x : ℤ | ∃ y : ℤ, f y = 0 ∧ x = y ^ 2}) : a ^ 2013 + b ^ 2013 + c ^ 2013 = -1 := by

informal_statement:
The function $f$ is not defined for $x = 0,$ but for all non-zero real numbers $x,$
\[f(x) + 2f \left( \frac{1}{x} \right) = 3x.\]Find the real solutions to $f(x) = f(-x).$  Enter the real solutions, separated by commas.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The function $f$ is not defined for $x = 0,$ but for all non-zero real numbers $x,$
\[f(x) + 2f \left( \frac{1}{x} \right) = 3x.\]Find the real solutions to $f(x) = f(-x).$  Enter the real solutions, separated by commas. -/
theorem algebra_12592 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ∀ {x}, x ≠ 0 → f x + 2 * f (1 / x) = 3 * x) : {x | x ≠ 0 ∧ f x = f (-x)} = {√2, -√2} := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- The function $f$ is not defined for $x = 0,$ but for all non-zero real numbers $x,$
\[f(x) + 2f \left( \frac{1}{x} \right) = 3x.\]Find the real solutions to $f(x) = f(-x).$  Enter the real solutions, separated by commas. -/
theorem algebra_12592 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ∀ {x}, x ≠ 0 → f x + 2 * f (1 / x) = 3 * x) : {x | x ≠ 0 ∧ f x = f (-x)} = {√2, -√2} := by

  -- We have f x = (2 - x^2) / x for all x ≠ 0
  have H {x} (hx : x ≠ 0) : f x = (2 - x ^ 2) / x := by
    -- Plug in x and 1 / x into the equation hf
    have h1 := hf hx
    have h2 := hf (show 1 / x ≠ 0 from one_div_ne_zero hx)
    -- Simplify h2
    rw [show 1 / (1 / x) = x by simp] at h2
    -- Simplify the goal
    rw [show (2 - x ^ 2) / x = 2 * (1 / x) - x by field_simp; ring]
    -- Solve the linear equations
    linarith

  ext x
  simp
  -- Two goals:
  -- 1. Show that f x = f (-x) (x ≠ 0) implies x = √2 or x = -√2
  -- 2. Show that x = √2 or x = -√2 implies f x = f (-x) (x ≠ 0)
  constructor
  . -- Goal 1
    rintro ⟨h1, h2⟩
    -- Use the lemma H to eliminate f
    rw [H h1, H (show -x ≠ 0 from mt neg_eq_zero.1 h1)] at h2
    simp [div_neg] at h2
    replace h2 : (2 - x ^ 2) / x = 0 := by linarith only [h2]
    simp [h1] at h2
    -- After simplification, 2 - x^2 = 0
    rw [← sq_eq_sq_iff_eq_or_eq_neg]
    simp
    linarith only [h2]

  . -- Goal 2
    -- Just plug in x = √2 or x = -√2 into the equation H
    rintro (rfl | rfl)
    . simp [H]
    . simp [H]

informal_statement: Montrer que pour tout entier n , le nombre $\mathrm{n}^{3}-7 \mathrm{n}$ est divisible par 6 .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Int

-- Theorem: For any integer n, 6 divides n³ - 7n
theorem number_theory_607371 (n : ℤ) : 6 ∣ n^3 - 7 * n := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Int

-- Theorem: For any integer n, 6 divides n³ - 7n
theorem number_theory_607371 (n : ℤ) : 6 ∣ n^3 - 7 * n := by
  -- Let r be the remainder of n modulo 6, i.e., n ≡ r mod 6 with 0 ≤ r < 6
  let r := n % 6

  -- Establish the congruence n ≡ r mod 6
  have h : ModEq 6 n r := ModEq.symm (Int.mod_modEq _ _)

  -- Use properties of congruences:
  -- If n ≡ r mod 6, then n³ ≡ r³ and 7n ≡ 7r mod 6,
  -- so n³ - 7n ≡ r³ - 7r mod 6
  have mod_eq : n^3 - 7 * n ≡ r^3 - 7 * r [ZMOD 6] :=
    (h.pow 3).sub (h.mul_left 7)

  -- Confirm that r ∈ {0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5}
  have r_nonneg : 0 ≤ r := Int.emod_nonneg _ (by decide)
  have r_lt : r < 6 := Int.emod_lt _ (by decide)
  have r_range : 0 ≤ r ∧ r < 6 := ⟨r_nonneg, r_lt⟩

  -- Use case analysis on the 6 possible values of r
  interval_cases r

  case «0» =>
    -- r = 0 → r³ - 7r = 0 - 0 = 0 ≡ 0 mod 6
    exact Int.modEq_zero_iff_dvd.mp (mod_eq.trans (ModEq.refl 0))

  case «1» =>
    -- r = 1 → 1³ - 7*1 = -6 ≡ 0 mod 6
    exact Int.modEq_zero_iff_dvd.mp (mod_eq.trans (ModEq.refl (-6)))

  case «2» =>
    -- r = 2 → 8 - 14 = -6 ≡ 0 mod 6
    exact Int.modEq_zero_iff_dvd.mp (mod_eq.trans (ModEq.refl (-6)))

  case «3» =>
    -- r = 3 → 27 - 21 = 6 ≡ 0 mod 6
    exact Int.modEq_zero_iff_dvd.mp (mod_eq.trans (ModEq.refl (6)))

  case «4» =>
    -- r = 4 → 64 - 28 = 36 ≡ 0 mod 6
    exact Int.modEq_zero_iff_dvd.mp (mod_eq.trans (ModEq.refl (36)))

  case «5» =>
    -- r = 5 → 125 - 35 = 90 ≡ 0 mod 6
    exact Int.modEq_zero_iff_dvd.mp (mod_eq.trans (ModEq.refl (90)))

informal_statement: JPN   Find all functions $f$ from the set of real numbers into the set of real numbers which satisfy for all real $x, y$ the identity  $$ f(x f(x+y))=f(y f(x))+x^{2} $$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- JPN   Find all functions $f$ from the set of real numbers into the set of real numbers which satisfy for all real $x, y$ the identity  $$ f(x f(x+y))=f(y f(x))+x^{2} $$ -/
theorem algebra_23811 (f : ℝ → ℝ) :
    (∀ x y, f (x * f (x + y)) = f (y * f x) + x ^ 2) ↔ ((∀ x, f x = x) ∨ (∀ x, f x = -x)) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- JPN   Find all functions $f$ from the set of real numbers into the set of real numbers which satisfy for all real $x, y$ the identity  $$ f(x f(x+y))=f(y f(x))+x^{2} $$ -/
theorem algebra_23811 (f : ℝ → ℝ) :
    (∀ x y, f (x * f (x + y)) = f (y * f x) + x ^ 2) ↔ ((∀ x, f x = x) ∨ (∀ x, f x = -x)) := by
  -- Break the goal into two implications.
  apply Iff.intro
  . intro h₀
    -- Show that f(0) = 0.
    have h₁ : f 0 = 0 := by
      by_contra!
      -- If f(0) ≠ 0, f is a constant.
      have h₁ (t : ℝ) : f t = f 0 := by
        have h₂ : f (0 * f (0 + t / f 0)) = f (t / f 0 * f 0) + 0 ^ 2 := h₀ 0 (t / f 0)
        simp [this] at h₂
        rw [h₂]
      have h₂ (x : ℝ) : x = 0 := by
        have h₃ : f (x * f (x + 0)) = f (0 * f x) + x ^ 2 := h₀ x 0
        simp [h₁ (x * f x)] at h₃
        exact h₃
      absurd h₂
      simp
      use 1
      norm_num
    have h₂ (t : ℝ) := h₀ t 0
    simp [h₁] at h₂
    have h₃ (t : ℝ) := h₀ t (-t)
    simp [h₁] at h₃
    -- Show that f(t) = 0 ↔ t = 0.
    have h₄ (t : ℝ) : f t = 0 → t = 0 := by
      intro h₄
      have h₅ := h₀ t 0
      simp [h₄] at h₅
      exact h₅
    -- Show that f is odd.
    have h₅ (s : ℝ) : f s = -f (-s) := by
      by_cases h₅ : f s = 0
      . apply h₄ s at h₅
        subst s
        simp [h₁]
      . rw [<-ne_eq, ne_iff_lt_or_gt] at h₅
        cases h₅ with
        | inl h₅ =>
          -- Let t be a number such that f(s) = -t².
          let t := Real.sqrt (-f s)
          have h₆ : f s = -t ^ 2 := by
            simp [t]
            rw [Real.sq_sqrt]
            simp
            linarith only [h₅]
          have h₇ : f t ≠ 0 := by
            by_contra! h₇
            apply h₄ t at h₇
            rw [h₇] at h₆
            linarith only [h₅, h₆]
          -- Let a be a number such that af(t) = s.
          let a := s / f t
          have h₈ : a * f t = s := by
            simp [a]
            rw [div_mul_cancel₀]
            exact h₇
          -- Substitute (x, y) = (t, a) into the original equation.
          have h₉ := h₀ t a
          simp [h₈, h₆] at h₉
          apply h₄ at h₉
          simp at h₉
          cases h₉ with
          | inl h₉ =>
            rw [h₉] at h₆
            linarith only [h₅, h₆]
          | inr h₉ =>
            apply h₄ at h₉
            rw [add_comm, add_eq_zero_iff_eq_neg] at h₉
            simp [h₉] at h₈
            simp [<-h₈, h₂ t]
            linarith only [h₃ t]
        | inr h₅ =>
          -- Let t be a number such that f(s) = t².
          let t := Real.sqrt (f s)
          have h₆ : f s = t ^ 2 := by
            simp [t]
            rw [Real.sq_sqrt]
            linarith only [h₅]
          have h₇ : t ≠ 0 := by
            by_contra! h₇
            rw [h₇] at h₆
            linarith only [h₅, h₆]
          have h₈ : f t ≠ 0 := by
            contrapose! h₇
            exact h₄ t h₇
          have h₉ : s ≠ 0 := by
            by_contra! h₉
            subst h₉
            linarith only [h₁, h₅]
          -- Let a be a number such that tf(a) = s.
          let a' := Real.sqrt |s / t|
          let a := if s / t > 0 then a' * f a' else -a' * f a'
          have h₁₀ : t * f a = s := by
            have h₁₀ : s / t ≠ 0 := by
              simp [h₇, h₉]
            rw [ne_iff_lt_or_gt, or_comm] at h₁₀
            cases h₁₀ with
            | inl h₁₀ =>
              simp [a]
              rw [if_pos h₁₀]
              rw [h₂]
              simp [a', abs, le_of_lt h₁₀]
              rw [mul_div_cancel₀ _ h₇]
            | inr h₁₀ =>
              simp [a]
              replace h₁₀ : ¬s / t > 0 := by
                rw [not_lt]
                exact le_of_lt h₁₀
              rw [if_neg h₁₀]
              rw [show f (-(a' * f a')) = -a' ^ 2 by linarith only [h₃ a']]
              simp at h₁₀
              simp [a', abs, h₁₀]
              rw [mul_div_cancel₀ _ h₇]
          -- Substitute (x, y) = (t, a - t) into the original equation.-
          have h₁₁ := h₀ t (a - t)
          simp [h₁₀, <-h₆] at h₁₁
          apply h₄ at h₁₁
          simp [h₈] at h₁₁
          rw [show t = a by linarith only [h₁₁]] at h₁₀
          rw [<-h₁₀, h₂ a]
          linarith only [h₃ a]
    have h₅ (s : ℝ) : f (-s) = -f s := by
      linarith only [h₅ s]
    -- Substitute (x, y) = (s, t), (x, y) = (t, -s - t), (x, y) = (-s - t, s) into the original equation.
    have h₆ (s t : ℝ) := h₀ s t
    have h₇ (s t : ℝ) := h₀ t (-(s + t))
    have h₈ (s t : ℝ) := h₀ (-(s + t)) s
    replace h₇ (s t : ℝ) : -f (t * f s) = -f ((s + t) * f t) + t ^ 2 := by
      specialize h₇ s t
      rw [neg_mul, h₅] at h₇
      simp [h₅] at h₇
      exact h₇
    replace h₈ (s t : ℝ) : f ((s + t) * f t) = -f (s * f (s + t)) + (s + t) ^ 2 := by
      specialize h₈ s t
      rw [neg_mul, h₅, h₅, mul_neg, h₅, neg_sq] at h₈
      simp [h₅] at h₈
      exact h₈
    -- Adding these three equations together, we get f(tf(s)) = ts for all s, t ∈ ℝ.
    have h₉ (s t : ℝ) : f (t * f s) = t * s := by
      linarith only [h₆ s t, h₇ s t, h₈ s t]
    let s := f 1
    have h₁₀ : f s = 1 := by
      specialize h₂ 1
      simp at h₂
      simp [s, h₂]
    replace h₉ (t : ℝ) : f t = t * s := by
      specialize h₉ s t
      simp [h₁₀] at h₉
      exact h₉
    -- Show that s² = 1.
    specialize h₀ s 0
    simp [h₁₀, h₁] at h₀
    replace h₀ : (s - 1) * (s + 1) = 0 := by
      linarith only [h₀]
    simp at h₀
    cases h₀ with
    | inl h₁₁ =>
      replace h₁₁ : s = 1 := by
        linarith only [h₁₁]
      simp [h₁₁] at h₉
      left
      exact h₉
    | inr h₁₁ =>
      replace h₁₁ : s = -1 := by
        linarith only [h₁₁]
      simp [h₁₁] at h₉
      right
      exact h₉
  . -- Show that f(x) = x and f(x) = -x satisfy the condition.
    rintro (h | h) x y
    . rw [h, h, h, h]
      ring_nf
    . rw [h, h, h, h]
      ring_nf

soln_description:
$$
\binom{2 p-1}{p-1}-1=\frac{(p+1)(p+2) \ldots(p+p-1)-(p-1)!}{(p-1)!}
$$

To prove the statement, it is sufficient to show that the numerator of (1) is divisible by $p^{2}$, since if $(p-1)!\left(\binom{2 p-1}{p-1}-1\right)$ is divisible by $p^{2}$, then $\binom{2 p-1}{p-1}-1$ is as well, because $p^{2}$ and $(p-1)!$ are relatively prime. So let's look at the first term of the numerator of (1):

$$
\begin{gathered}
(p+1)(p+2) \ldots(p+p-1)=\prod_{i=1}^{\frac{p-1}{2}}(p+i) \ldots(p+(p-i))= \\
=\prod_{i=1}^{\frac{p-1}{2}}\left(2 p^{2}+i(p-i)\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Since we are examining divisibility by $p^{2}$, it is enough to consider the remainder of the above product when divided by $p^{2}$, which is $\prod_{i=1}^{\frac{p-1}{2}} i(p-i) = (p-1)!$.

Therefore, $(p+1)(p+2) \ldots(p+p-1)-(p-1)!$ is indeed divisible by $p^{2}$. Based on the work of Zsuzsanna Vaik (Budapest, Berzsenyi D. Gymnasium, III. grade)
informal_statement: Prove that if $p$ is an odd prime, then $\binom{2 p-1}{p-1}-1$ is divisible by $p^{2}$!
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove that if $p$ is an odd prime, then $\binom{2 p-1}{p-1}-1$ is divisible by $p^{2}$! -/
theorem number_theory_207926 (p : ℕ) (hp : Odd p ∧ Nat.Prime p) :
    p^2 ∣ (Nat.choose (2 * p - 1) (p - 1) - 1) := by

soln_description:
(1) Necessity. From the given, we have $a_{1}=a_{2}=1, a_{3}=m, a_{4}=k+m, a_{5}=m^{2}+k m+k, a_{6}=\frac{(k+m)\left(m^{2}+k m+k\right)+k}{m}$, then
$$
(k+m)\left(m^{2}+k m+k\right)+k \equiv k^{2}+k=k(k+1)(\bmod m) \text { and }(k, m)=1,
$$

so $m \mid k+1$ i.e., $k=r m-1$.
(2) Sufficiency. When $k=r m-1$,
$$
a_{n+1} a_{n-2}=k+a_{n} a_{n-1}, a_{n+2} a_{n-1}=k+a_{n+1} a_{n},
$$

subtracting the two equations gives $a_{n+1}\left(a_{n-2}+a_{n}\right)=a_{n-1}\left(a_{n}+a_{n+2}\right)$, i.e., $\frac{a_{n}+a_{n+2}}{a_{n+1}}=\frac{a_{n-2}+a_{n}}{a_{n-1}}$, thus
$$
\frac{a_{n}+a_{n+2}}{a_{n+1}}=\frac{a_{n-2}+a_{n}}{a_{n-1}}=\frac{a_{n-4}+a_{n-2}}{a_{n-3}}=\cdots
$$

Assume when $n=s$, $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{s}$ are integers.
If $s+1$ is odd, $\frac{a_{s-1}+a_{s+1}}{a_{s}}=\frac{a_{s-3}+a_{s-1}}{a_{s-2}}=\frac{a_{s-5}+a_{s-3}}{a_{s-4}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{1}+a_{3}}{a_{2}}=$ $m+1$, so $a_{s+1}=(m+1) a_{s}-a_{s-1}$ is an integer;

If $s+1$ is even, $\frac{a_{s-1}+a_{s+1}}{a_{s}}=\frac{a_{s-3}+a_{s-1}}{a_{s-2}}=\frac{a_{s-5}+a_{s-3}}{a_{s-1}}=\cdots=\frac{a_{2}+a_{4}}{a_{3}}=$ $r+1$, so $a_{s+1}=(r+1) a_{s}-a_{s-1}$ is an integer.
Therefore, for all positive integers $n, a_{n}$ are integers.
informal_statement:
$$
\text { 3.20 ** Sequence }\left\{a_{n}\right\} \text {, where } a_{1}=a_{2}=1, a_{3}=m, a_{n+1}=\frac{k+a_{n} a_{n-1}}{a_{n-2}}(n \geqslant 3) \text {, }
$$

where $k, m$ are coprime integers.
Prove that $a_{n}$ are all integers if and only if $k=r m-1$ $(r \in \mathbf{Z})$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $$
\text { 3.20 ** Sequence }\left\{a_{n}\right\} \text {, where } a_{1}=a_{2}=1, a_{3}=m, a_{n+1}=\frac{k+a_{n} a_{n-1}}{a_{n-2}}(n \geqslant 3) \text {, }
$$

where $k, m$ are coprime integers.
Prove that $a_{n}$ are all integers if and only if $k=r m-1$ $(r \in \mathbf{Z})$.
 -/
theorem number_theory_213939 (a : ℕ → ℝ) (k m : ℤ) (hk : a 1 = 1) (hm : a 2 = 1)
    (h3 : a 3 = m) (h : ∀ n ≥ 3, a (n + 1) = (k + a n * a (n - 1)) / a (n - 2))
    (hk' : IsCoprime k m) :
    (∀ n, ∃ m : ℤ, a n = m) ↔ ∃ r : ℤ, k = r * m - 1 := by

informal_statement: Let $p(x)$ be a monic polynomial of degree 4.  Three of the roots of $p(x)$ are 1, 2, and 3.  Find $p(0) + p(4).$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $p(x)$ be a monic polynomial of degree 4.  Three of the roots of $p(x)$ are 1, 2, and 3.  Find $p(0) + p(4).$ -/
theorem algebra_22218 {p : Polynomial ℝ} 
    (hp : p.Monic) (hroots : {1, 2, 3} ≤ p.roots) 
    (hpdegree : p.degree = 4) :
    p.eval 0 + p.eval 4 = 24 := by

soln_description:
To find the number of solutions in nonnegative integers \(x, y, z\) with \(x \le y \le z\) for the equation 
\[ 8^k = x^3 + y^3 + z^3 - 3xyz, \]
we will use mathematical induction.

1. **Base Case: \(k = 0\)**
   \[
   8^0 = 1 = x^3 + y^3 + z^3 - 3xyz.
   \]
   We need to find nonnegative integer solutions \((x, y, z)\) such that \(x \le y \le z\). 

   Consider the equation:
   \[
   x^3 + y^3 + z^3 - 3xyz = (x + y + z)(x^2 + y^2 + z^2 - xy - xz - yz).
   \]
   For \(1 = (x + y + z)(x^2 + y^2 + z^2 - xy - xz - yz)\), we need to find the values of \(x, y, z\) that satisfy this equation. 

   The only solution in nonnegative integers is:
   \[
   (x, y, z) = (0, 0, 1).
   \]
   Therefore, for \(k = 0\), there is exactly 1 solution.

2. **Inductive Step:**
   Assume that for \(k = n-1\), there are \(n\) solutions. We need to show that for \(k = n\), there are \(n+1\) solutions.

   Given the equation for \(k = n-1\):
   \[
   8^{n-1} = x^3 + y^3 + z^3 - 3xyz,
   \]
   we assume there are \(n\) solutions \((x_i, y_i, z_i)\) for \(i = 1, 2, \ldots, n\).

   Now consider the equation for \(k = n\):
   \[
   8^n = x^3 + y^3 + z^3 - 3xyz.
   \]
   We can generate solutions for \(k = n\) by multiplying each solution \((x_i, y_i, z_i)\) of \(k = n-1\) by 2:
   \[
   (2x_i, 2y_i, 2z_i).
   \]
   This gives us \(n\) solutions for \(k = n\).

   Additionally, for any solution \((x, y, z)\) where \(x, y, z\) are all even, dividing each by 2 gives a solution for \(k = n-1\). Since we have \(n\) solutions for \(k = n-1\), we get \(n\) even-even-even solutions for \(k = n\).

   Therefore, we have \(n + 1\) solutions for \(k = n\).

By induction, we have shown that for any positive integer \(k\), the number of solutions in nonnegative integers \(x, y, z\) with \(x \le y \le z\) of the equation \(8^k = x^3 + y^3 + z^3 - 3xyz\) is \(k + 1\).

\(\blacksquare\)

The final answer is \( \boxed{ k + 1 } \).
informal_statement:
For each positive integer $k$ find the number of solutions in nonnegative integers $x,y,z$ with $x\le y \le z$ of the equation
$$8^k=x^3+y^3+z^3-3xyz$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- For each positive integer $k$ find the number of solutions in nonnegative integers $x,y,z$ with $x\le y \le z$ of the equation
$$8^k=x^3+y^3+z^3-3xyz$$ -/
theorem number_theory_52363 (k : ℕ) (hk : 0 < k) :
    {(x, y, z) : ℕ × ℕ × ℕ | x ≤ y ∧ y ≤ z ∧ 8 ^ k = x ^ 3 + y ^ 3 + z ^ 3 - 3 * x * y * z}.ncard = k + 1 := by

informal_statement:
Angela has deposited $\$8,\!000$ into an account that pays $6\%$ interest compounded annually.

Bob has deposited $\$10,\!000$ into an account that pays $7\%$ simple annual interest.

In $20$ years Angela and Bob compare their respective balances. To the nearest dollar, what is the positive difference between their balances?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Angela has deposited $\$8,\!000$ into an account that pays $6\%$ interest compounded annually.

Bob has deposited $\$10,\!000$ into an account that pays $7\%$ simple annual interest.

In $20$ years Angela and Bob compare their respective balances. To the nearest dollar, what is the positive difference between their balances? -/
theorem algebra_14711 (A B : ℝ) (hA : A = 8000) (hB : B = 10000)
    (hA' : A' = 0.06) (hB' : B' = 0.07) :
    round |A * (1 + A') ^ 20 - B * (1 + B' * 20)| = 1657 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Angela has deposited $\$8,\!000$ into an account that pays $6\%$ interest compounded annually.

Bob has deposited $\$10,\!000$ into an account that pays $7\%$ simple annual interest.

In $20$ years Angela and Bob compare their respective balances. To the nearest dollar, what is the positive difference between their balances? -/
theorem algebra_14711 (A B : ℝ) (hA : A = 8000) (hB : B = 10000)
    (hA' : A' = 0.06) (hB' : B' = 0.07) :
    round |A * (1 + A') ^ 20 - B * (1 + B' * 20)| = 1657 := by
  subst_vars
  norm_num [round_eq]
  simp [abs_of_pos]
  norm_num

soln_description:
First, we rewrite the given polynomial as follows:
$$b^2 - c^2 + a(a + 2b) = b^2 - c^2 + a^2 + 2ab$$
This can be further simplified by recognizing it as a difference of squares and rearranging:
$$= (a + b)^2 - c^2$$
Finally, we apply the difference of squares formula:
$$= (a + b + c)(a + b - c)$$
Therefore, the factorized form of the given polynomial is $\boxed{(a + b + c)(a + b - c)}$.
informal_statement: Factorize the polynomial $b^2 - c^2 + a(a + 2b)$ within the range of rational numbers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Factorize the polynomial $b^2 - c^2 + a(a + 2b)$ within the range of rational numbers. -/
theorem algebra_9429 {a b c : ℚ} : b^2 - c^2 + a * (a + 2 * b) = (a + b + c) * (a + b - c) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Factorize the polynomial $b^2 - c^2 + a(a + 2b)$ within the range of rational numbers. -/
theorem algebra_9429 {a b c : ℚ} : b^2 - c^2 + a * (a + 2 * b) = (a + b + c) * (a + b - c) := by
  -- Equality in ring
  ring

soln_description:
Solution. Assuming $x, y>0$, by adding the two equations and dividing both sides of the obtained equation by 2, we get:

$$
1=\frac{3}{\sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{y}}
$$

By subtracting the first equation from the second and dividing both sides by 2:

$$
\frac{12}{3 x+y}=\frac{3}{\sqrt{y}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}
$$

Multiplying equations (1) and (2):

$$
\frac{12}{3 x+y}=\frac{9}{y}-\frac{1}{x}=\frac{9 x-y}{x y}
$$

After bringing to a common denominator:

$$
12 x y=(9 x-y)(3 x+y)=27 x^{2}+6 x y-y^{2}
$$

Factoring the quadratic equation: $(3 x-y) \cdot(9 x+y)=0$. Since $x, y>0$, only $3 x-y=0$ is possible, so $x=\frac{y}{3}$. Substituting this into (1):

$$
1=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{y}}+\frac{3}{\sqrt{y}}
$$

From this, $\sqrt{y}=3+\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow y=12+6 \sqrt{3}$ and $x=4+2 \sqrt{3}$.

Therefore, the solution to the system of equations is: $x=4+2 \sqrt{3} \approx 7.464, y=12+6 \sqrt{3} \approx 22.392$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Solve the following system of equations:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 1-\frac{12}{3 x+y}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{x}} \\
& 1+\frac{12}{3 x+y}=\frac{6}{\sqrt{y}}
\end{aligned}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_207958 :
  { (x, y) : ℝ × ℝ | x > 0 ∧ y > 0 ∧
    1 - 12 / (3 * x + y) = 2 / Real.sqrt x ∧
    1 + 12 / (3 * x + y) = 6 / Real.sqrt y }
  =
  { (4 + 2 * Real.sqrt 3, 12 + 6 * Real.sqrt 3) } := by

informal_statement: Evaluate the infinite geometric series: $$\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{6}+\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{24}+\dots$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Evaluate the infinite geometric series: $$\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{6}+\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{24}+\dots$$ -/
theorem algebra_15079 : ∑' n : ℕ, (1 / 3 : ℝ) * (1 / 2) ^ n = 2 / 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Evaluate the infinite geometric series: $$\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{6}+\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{24}+\dots$$ -/
theorem algebra_15079 : ∑' n : ℕ, (1 / 3 : ℝ) * (1 / 2) ^ n = 2 / 3 := by
  apply HasSum.tsum_eq
  -- The sum is a geometric series with first term 1/3 and common ratio 1/2
  rw [show (2 / 3 : ℝ) = (1 / 3 : ℝ) • 2 by norm_num]
  -- It suffices to show that the sum of the series (1/2)^n is 2
  apply HasSum.const_smul
  nth_rw 2 [show 2 = (1 - (1 / 2) : ℝ)⁻¹ by norm_num]
  -- Use the formula for the sum of a geometric series
  -- If 0 ≤ r < 1, the sum of the series is 1 / (1 - r)
  apply hasSum_geometric_of_lt_one
  all_goals
    norm_num

informal_statement:
Let $a_{0}, a_{1}, \ldots$ and $b_{0}, b_{1}, \ldots$ be geometric sequences with common ratios $r_{a}$ and $r_{b}$, respectively, such that

$$
\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} a_{i}=\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} b_{i}=1 \quad \text { and } \quad\left(\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} b_{i}^{2}\right)=\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} a_{i} b_{i} .
$$

Find the smallest real number $c$ such that $a_{0}<c$ must be true.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/-
Let $a_{0}, a_{1}, \ldots$ and $b_{0}, b_{1}, \ldots$ be geometric sequences with common ratios $r_{a}$ and $r_{b}$, respectively, such that

$$
\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} a_{i}=\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} b_{i}=1 \quad \text { and } \quad\left(\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} b_{i}^{2}\right)=\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} a_{i} b_{i} .
$$

Find the smallest real number $c$ such that $a_{0}<c$ must be true.
-/

theorem a609912 (a b : ℝ) (ra rb : ℝ) (asrs : ℕ → ℝ) (bsrs : ℕ → ℝ)
(ratio1 : |ra| < 1)
(ratio2 : |rb| < 1)
(adef : ∀ i, asrs i = a*(ra^i)) (bdef : ∀ i, bsrs i = b*(rb^i))
(h1 : ∑' i : ℕ, asrs i = 1) (h2 : ∑' i : ℕ, bsrs i = 1)
(h3 : (∑' i : ℕ, (asrs i)^2) * (∑' i : ℕ, (bsrs i)^2) = ∑' i : ℕ, ((asrs i) * (bsrs i))) :
∃ c : ℝ, (asrs 0 < c ∧ (∀ d, ((asrs 0) < d) → c ≤ d)) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/-
Let $a_{0}, a_{1}, \ldots$ and $b_{0}, b_{1}, \ldots$ be geometric sequences with common ratios $r_{a}$ and $r_{b}$, respectively, such that

$$
\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} a_{i}=\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} b_{i}=1 \quad \text { and } \quad\left(\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} a_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} b_{i}^{2}\right)=\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} a_{i} b_{i} .
$$

Find the smallest real number $c$ such that $a_{0}<c$ must be true.
-/

theorem a609912 (a b : ℝ) (ra rb : ℝ) (asrs : ℕ → ℝ) (bsrs : ℕ → ℝ)
(ratio1 : |ra| < 1)
(ratio2 : |rb| < 1)
(adef : ∀ i, asrs i = a*(ra^i)) (bdef : ∀ i, bsrs i = b*(rb^i))
(h1 : ∑' i : ℕ, asrs i = 1) (h2 : ∑' i : ℕ, bsrs i = 1)
(h3 : (∑' i : ℕ, (asrs i)^2) * (∑' i : ℕ, (bsrs i)^2) = ∑' i : ℕ, ((asrs i) * (bsrs i))) :
∃ c : ℝ, (asrs 0 < c ∧ (∀ d, ((asrs 0) < d) → c ≤ d)) := by 
  use (4/3)
  have obv1 : asrs 0 = a := by {
    specialize adef 0
    simp at adef
    assumption
    }
  have hleft : asrs 0 < 4/3 := by
  { 
    have obv2 : bsrs 0 = b := by {
      specialize bdef 0
      simp at bdef
      assumption
    }
    rw [obv1]
    have lem1 : ∑' i, asrs i = asrs 0 / (1 - ra) := by {
      rw [tsum_congr adef, tsum_mul_left, tsum_geometric_of_abs_lt_one]
      ring_nf; rw [obv1, mul_comm]; exact ratio1
    }
    have lem2 : ∑' i, bsrs i = bsrs 0 / (1 - rb) := by {
      rw [tsum_congr bdef, tsum_mul_left, tsum_geometric_of_abs_lt_one]
      ring_nf; rw [obv2, mul_comm]; exact ratio2
    }
    have ezlema : asrs 0 / (1 - ra) = 1 := by rw [← lem1, h1]
    have ezlemb : bsrs 0 / (1 - rb) = 1 := by rw [← lem2, h2]
    have lema : a = 1 - ra := by {
      rw [← obv1]
      apply eq_of_div_eq_one
      exact ezlema
    }
    have lemb : b = 1 - rb := by {
      rw [← obv2]
      apply eq_of_div_eq_one
      exact ezlemb
    } 
    -- compute ∑ asrs i ^ 2 = a^2 / (1 - ra^2)
    have asq_def : ∀ i, (asrs i)^2 = a^2 * (ra^2)^i := by
      intro i
      rw [adef i]
      ring_nf

    have sa2 : ∑' i, (asrs i)^2 = a^2 / (1 - ra^2) := by
      rw [tsum_congr asq_def]
      have h := tsum_geometric_of_abs_lt_one (by linarith [ratio1])
      rw [sq, tsum_mul_left, tsum_geometric_of_abs_lt_one]
      ring_nf
      rw [← sq_abs]
      norm_num
      apply ratio1

    -- compute ∑ bsrs i ^ 2 = b^2 / (1 - rb^2)
    have bsq_def : ∀ i, (bsrs i)^2 = b^2 * (rb^2)^i := by
      intro i
      rw [bdef i]
      ring_nf

    have sb2 : ∑' i, (bsrs i)^2 = b^2 / (1 - rb^2) := by
      rw [tsum_congr bsq_def]
      have h := tsum_geometric_of_abs_lt_one (by linarith [ratio2])
      rw [sq, tsum_mul_left, tsum_geometric_of_abs_lt_one]
      ring_nf
      rw [← sq_abs]
      norm_num
      apply ratio2

    -- compute ∑ asrs i * bsrs i = ab / (1 - ra * rb)
    have ab_def : ∀ i, asrs i * bsrs i = a * b * (ra * rb)^i := by
      intro i
      rw [adef i, bdef i]
      ring_nf

    have sab : ∑' i, asrs i * bsrs i = a * b / (1 - ra * rb) := by
      rw [tsum_congr ab_def]
      have h := @tsum_geometric_of_abs_lt_one (ra * rb) (by {
        rw [abs_mul]
        sorry
      })
      rw [tsum_mul_left, h]
      ring

    -- plug into h3
    rw [sa2, sb2, sab] at h3
    rw [lema, lemb] at h3

    -- known algebraic identity: (2a - 3)(2b - 3) = 1
    have id : (2 * a - 3) * (2 * b - 3) = 1 := by
      sorry

    -- bound b to conclude a < 4/3
    have bpos : 0 < b := by
      rw [lemb]
      sorry

    have blt : b < 2 := by
      rw [lemb]
      sorry

    have range : -3 < 2 * b - 3 ∧ 2 * b - 3 < 1 := by
      constructor
      nlinarith
      nlinarith

    have not_one : 2 * b - 3 ≠ 1 := by
      linarith

    have aeq : 2 * a - 3 = 1 / (2 * b - 3) := by
      rw [← id]
      ring_nf
      sorry

    have : 2 * a - 3 < -1 / 3 := by
      rw [aeq]
      sorry

    rw [lema]
    nlinarith
  }
  constructor
  exact hleft
  case h.right =>
    intro d hd
    have : a < 4 / 3 := by {
      rw [← obv1]
      exact hleft
    }
    rw [obv1] at hd
    sorry

informal_statement:
For each integer $n\ge2$ prove the inequality
$$\log_23+\log_34+\ldots+\log_n(n+1)<n+\ln n-0.9.$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- For each integer $n\ge2$ prove the inequality
$$\log_23+\log_34+\ldots+\log_n(n+1)<n+\ln n-0.9.$$ -/
theorem negated_inequalities_52395 (n : ℕ)
    (hn : 2 ≤ n) : 
    ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 2 n, logb i (i + 1) < n + log n - 0.9 := by

informal_statement:
Let $f: \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}$ be a function satisfying $f(0) \neq 0, f(1)=0$ and

(i) $f(x y)+f(x) f(y)=f(x)+f(y)$;

(ii) $(f(x-y)-f(0)) f(x) f(y)=0$,

for all $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$, simultaneously.

(a) Find the set of all possible values of the function $f$.

(b) If $f(10) \neq 0$ and $f(2)=0$, find the set of all integers $n$ such that $f(n) \neq 0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $f: \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}$ be a function satisfying $f(0) \neq 0, f(1)=0$ and

(i) $f(x y)+f(x) f(y)=f(x)+f(y)$;

(ii) $(f(x-y)-f(0)) f(x) f(y)=0$,

for all $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$, simultaneously.

(a) Find the set of all possible values of the function $f$.

(b) If $f(10) \neq 0$ and $f(2)=0$, find the set of all integers $n$ such that $f(n) \neq 0$. -/
theorem algebra_607861 {f : ℤ → ℤ} (h0 : f 0 ≠ 0) (h1 : f 1 = 0)
  (h2 : ∀ x y, f (x * y) + f x * f y = f x + f y)
  (h3 : ∀ x y, (f (x - y) - f 0) * f x * f y = 0) :
  (∀ x, f x = 0 ∨ f x = 1) ∧ (f 10 ≠ 0 → f 2 = 0 → {x | f x ≠ 0} = {x | 5 ∣ x}):= by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Let $f: \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}$ be a function satisfying $f(0) \neq 0, f(1)=0$ and

(i) $f(x y)+f(x) f(y)=f(x)+f(y)$;

(ii) $(f(x-y)-f(0)) f(x) f(y)=0$,

for all $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$, simultaneously.

(a) Find the set of all possible values of the function $f$.

(b) If $f(10) \neq 0$ and $f(2)=0$, find the set of all integers $n$ such that $f(n) \neq 0$. -/
theorem algebra_607861 {f : ℤ → ℤ} (h0 : f 0 ≠ 0) (h1 : f 1 = 0)
  (h2 : ∀ x y, f (x * y) + f x * f y = f x + f y)
  (h3 : ∀ x y, (f (x - y) - f 0) * f x * f y = 0) :
  (∀ x, f x = 0 ∨ f x = 1) ∧ (f 10 ≠ 0 → f 2 = 0 → {x | f x ≠ 0} = {x | 5 ∣ x}):= by
    -- $$ (f(x)-f(0)) f(x)=0 $$

    -- for all $x$ (since $f(0) \neq 0$ ). Thus either $f(x)=0$ or $f(x)=f(0)$, for all $x \in \mathbb{Z}$.
    have proofa : ∀ x, f x = 0 ∨ f x = 1 := by
      intro x
      
      specialize h3 x 0
      simp [h0] at h3
      rcases h3 with h3 | h3
      · 
        -- Now taking $x=y=0$ in (i), we see that $f(0)+f(0)^{2}=2 f(0)$. This shows that $f(0)=0$ or $f(0)=1$. Since $f(0) \neq 0$, we must have $f(0)=1$. We conclude that
        -- $$ \text { either } f(x)=0 \text { or } f(x)=1 \text { for each } x \in \mathbb{Z} $$
        -- This shows that the set of all possible value of $f(x)$ is ${0,1}$. This completes (a).
        specialize h2 0 0
        simp at h2
        nth_rw 3 [←mul_one (f 0)] at h2
        rw [Int.mul_eq_mul_left_iff h0] at h2
        simp [h2] at h3
        right
        linarith
      · tauto
    constructor
    · exact proofa
    · intro f10 f2
      -- Let $S={n \in \mathbb{Z} \mid f(n) \neq 0}$. Hence we must have $S={n \in \mathbb{Z} \mid f(n)=1}$ by (a).
      set S := {x | f x ≠ 0}
      --  Since $f(1)=0,1$ is not in $S$. And $f(0)=1$ implies that $0 \in S$. Take any $x \in \mathbb{Z}$ and $y \in S$. Using (ii), we get

      -- $$ f(x y)+f(x)=f(x)+1 $$

      -- This shows that $x y \in S$. If $x \in \mathbb{Z}$ and $y \in \mathbb{Z}$ are such that $x y \in S$, 
      have hA : ∀ x y, y ∈ S → x*y ∈ S := by
        intro x y yS
        simp [S] at yS ⊢
        have y1 : f y = 1 := by have := proofa y; tauto
        specialize  h2 x y
        simp [y1] at h2
        linarith
      -- then (ii) gives
      -- $$ 1+f(x) f(y)=f(x)+f(y) $$

      -- Thus $(f(x)-1)(f(y)-1)=0$. It follows that $f(x)=1$ or $f(y)=1$; i.e., either $x \in S$ or $y \in S$.
      have hB : ∀ x y, x*y ∈ S → x ∈ S ∨ y ∈ S := by
        intro x y xyS
        specialize h2 x y
        have : f (x*y) = 1 := by simp [S] at xyS; have := proofa (x*y); tauto
        simp [this] at h2
        simp [S]
        suffices ¬ (f x = 0 ∧ f y = 0) by tauto
        intro fxfy0
        simp [fxfy0] at h2
      -- Setting $y=0$ in the condition (ii), we get
      -- We also observe from (ii) that $x \in S$ and $y \in S$ implies that $f(x-y)=1$ so that $x-y \in S$. 
      have hC : ∀ x y, x ∈ S → y ∈ S → x - y ∈ S := by
        intro x y xS yS
        simp [S] at xS yS
        specialize h3 x y
        simp [xS, yS] at h3
        have := (Int.sub_eq_zero.1 h3) ▸ h0
        simp [S, this]
      -- Now we know that $f(10) \neq 0$ and $f(2)=0$. Hence $f(10)=1$ and $10 \in S$; and $2 \notin S$. Writing $10=2 \times 5$ and using (B), we conclude that $5 \in S$ and $f(5)=1$. Hence $f(5 k)=1$ for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}$ by (A).
      have h10 : 10 ∈ S := by simp [S, f10]
      have h2  : 2 ∉ S := by simp [S, f2]
      have h5  : 5 ∈ S := by have := hB 5 2 h10; tauto
      apply Set.eq_of_subset_of_subset
      · intro a as
        have a5 := Int.ediv_add_emod' a 5
        by_cases amod5 : a % 5 = 0
        · simp; exact Int.dvd_of_emod_eq_zero amod5
        · -- Suppose $f(5 k+l)=1$ for some $l, 1 \leq l \leq 4$. Then $5 k+l \in S$.
          set k := a / 5
          set l := a % 5
          -- Choose $u \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $l u \equiv 1(\bmod 5)$. 
          have ⟨u, hu⟩ : ∃ u, l * u ≡ 1 [ZMOD 5] := by
            use l^3
            rw [show l*l^3 = l^4 by nlinarith]
            apply Int.ModEq.pow_card_sub_one_eq_one Nat.prime_five
            have : l < 5 := by simp [l]; exact Int.emod_lt a (by omega)
            have : 0 < l := by
              have : 0 ≤ l := Int.emod_nonneg a (show 5 ≠ 0 by omega)
              omega
            interval_cases l <;> simp [Int.isCoprime_iff_gcd_eq_one] <;> decide
          -- We have $(5 k+l) u \in S$ by (A). 
          have umulS : u * (k * 5 + l) ∈ S := hA u _ (a5 ▸ as)
          have uk5S  : u * k * 5 ∈ S       := hA (u * k) _ h5
          -- --  Moreover, $l u=1+5 m$ for some $m \in \mathbb{Z}$ and
          -- $$ (5 k+l) u=5 k u+l u=5 k u+5 m+1=5(k u+m)+1 $$
          -- This shows that $5(k u+m)+1 \in S$. However, we know that $5(k u+m) \in S$. By (C), $1 \in S$ which is a contradiction.
          have oneS  : 1 ∈ S               := by
            have : l * u ∈ S := by convert hC _  _ umulS uk5S using 1; linarith
            have ⟨m, hm⟩ := Int.modEq_iff_add_fac.1 hu.symm
            convert hC _ _ this (show 5 * m ∈ S by convert hA m 5 h5 using 1; ring)
            simp [hm]
          simp [S] at oneS
          exfalso
          exact oneS h1
      · intro k ⟨y, hy ⟩
        simp [hy]
        convert hA y 5 h5  using 1
        ring

soln_description:
If the resistance of the light bulb is independent of the voltage, its power can be given by $U^{2} / R$. The operating cost of the light bulb over its entire lifetime is:

$$
E \cdot U^{2} /\left(R \cdot 10^{3}\right) \cdot a
$$

where $E\left(=E_{0} \cdot 2^{-0.1 U}\right)$ is the lifespan of the light bulb, $a(=2.1 \text{ Ft} / \text{kWh})$ is the operating cost, and $R(=200 \Omega)$ is the resistance of the light bulb.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_02_c3596721a2838b4bba0cg-1.jpg?height=940&width=903&top_left_y=381&top_left_x=600)

The light energy emitted per unit time is

$$
U^{2} /\left(R \cdot 10^{3}\right) G
$$

where $G\left(=G_{0} U^{1.7}\right)$ is the efficiency of light emission.

We can operate the light bulb at the lowest cost if the cost per unit time for unit light emission is the smallest, i.e., if the function

$$
f(U)=\frac{E U^{2} /\left(R \cdot 10^{3}\right) \cdot a + A}{E G U^{2} /\left(R \cdot 10^{3}\right)}
$$

has a minimum (where $A$ is the price of the light bulb). Substituting the expressions and simplifying, we get:

$$
f(U)=\alpha U^{-1.7}\left(1+\beta 2^{0.1 U} U^{-2}\right)
$$

where $\alpha=42.5$ and $\beta=0.372$, which we obtained based on the following data: $G_{0}=4 \cdot 10^{-2}$ candela $/ \text{kW}$, $a=2.1$ $\text{Ft} / \text{kWh}$, $E_{0}=2.048 \cdot 10^{6} \text{ h}$, $R=200 \Omega$, $A=8 \text{ Ft}$.

Our task is to find the minimum of the $f(U)$ function with respect to $U$. The simplest way to do this is to tabulate the $f(U)$ function. The part of the $f(U)$ function near its minimum is shown in the figure. From this, we can determine the $U$ value corresponding to the minimum, which is $\approx 138.5 \text{ V}$. Of course, we can also find the minimum by differentiation. In this case, we need to solve the equation $\frac{d f(U)}{d U}=0$. It is useful to use the transformation

$$
2^{0.1 U}=e^{0.1 U \ln 2}
$$

Using the power and chain rule for differentiation, we get:

$$
f^{\prime}(U)=-\frac{1.7 U^{-2.7} a}{G_{0}}+\frac{A K}{E_{0} G_{0} 10^{3}}\left(0.1 \cdot \ln 2 \cdot e^{0.1 U \ln 2} \cdot U^{-3.7}-e^{0.1 U \ln 2} \cdot 3.7 U^{-4.7}\right)
$$

The condition for the minimum is that $f^{\prime}(U)=0$; after simplifications, we get:

$$
e^{-0.1 U \cdot \ln 2}=\frac{A R U^{-1} 10^{3}}{1.7 \cdot a E_{0}}\left(0.1 \cdot \ln 2-3.7 U^{-1}\right)
$$

The solution to this equation can only be found by trial and error. A relatively simple way is to tabulate both sides and find the $U$ values where the two sides are approximately equal. We can see that this calculation is not simpler than plotting the $f(U)$ function.
informal_statement: The price of an incandescent lamp is $8 \mathrm{Ft}$, its lifetime as a function of voltage is $E=2 \cdot 10^{6} \cdot 2^{-U /(10 \mathrm{~V})}$ hours. Its efficiency (candela/watt) depends on the voltage: $G=4 \cdot 10^{-5}(U / 1 \mathrm{~V})^{1.7}$ candela/watt. The price of $1 \mathrm{kWh}$ of energy is $2.1 \mathrm{Ft}$. At what voltage should we operate the lamp to get the cheapest light over a longer period? The resistance of the filament is $R=200 \Omega$; assume it is independent of the voltage.

soln_description:
1. **Define the problem and assumptions:**
   Let \( A \subset \mathbb{C} \) be a closed and countable set. We are given that \( f: \mathbb{C} \setminus A \to \mathbb{C} \) is an analytic function that is bounded. We need to prove that \( f \) is constant.

2. **Boundedness and the collection \( \mathcal{S} \):**
   Since \( f \) is bounded, there exists a constant \( M \) such that \( |f(z)| \leq M \) for all \( z \in \mathbb{C} \setminus A \). Consider the collection \( \mathcal{S} \) of pairs \( (X, g) \) where \( X \) is an open set such that \( \mathbb{C} \setminus A \subset X \subset \mathbb{C} \) and \( g \) is an analytic extension of \( f \) to \( X \) with \( |g(z)| \leq M \) for all \( z \in X \).

3. **Ordering the collection \( \mathcal{S} \):**
   We order the collection \( \mathcal{S} \) by defining \( (X_1, g_1) \leq (X_2, g_2) \) if \( X_1 \subset X_2 \) and \( g_1(z) = g_2(z) \) for all \( z \in X_1 \).

4. **Applying Zorn's Lemma:**
   If \( \{(X_i, g_i)\} \) is a chain in \( \mathcal{S} \), then \( (\cup_{i} X_i, g) \) where \( g(z) = g_i(z) \) if \( z \in X_i \), is an upper bound of the chain. By Zorn's Lemma, there exists a maximal element \( (Y, h) \in \mathcal{S} \).

5. **Analyzing the maximal element \( (Y, h) \):**
   Since \( Y \) is an open set containing \( \mathbb{C} \setminus A \), the set \( \mathbb{C} \setminus Y \) is closed and countable. By Baire's Category Theorem, \( \mathbb{C} \setminus Y \) is either empty or has an isolated point.

6. **Case 1: \( \mathbb{C} \setminus Y \) is empty:**
   If \( \mathbb{C} \setminus Y \) is empty, then \( Y = \mathbb{C} \). Thus, \( h \) is an analytic function on the entire complex plane that is bounded. By Liouville's Theorem, \( h \) must be constant. Since \( h \) is an extension of \( f \), \( f \) must also be constant.

7. **Case 2: \( \mathbb{C} \setminus Y \) has an isolated point:**
   If \( \mathbb{C} \setminus Y \) has an isolated point \( z_0 \), we can extend \( h \) to \( z_0 \) because \( h \) is analytic and bounded near \( z_0 \). This would contradict the maximality of \( (Y, h) \) because we could create a larger pair \( (Y \cup \{z_0\}, h') \) where \( h' \) extends \( h \) to \( z_0 \). Therefore, this case cannot occur.

8. **Conclusion:**
   Since the case where \( \mathbb{C} \setminus Y \) has an isolated point leads to a contradiction, the only possibility is that \( \mathbb{C} \setminus Y \) is empty. Hence, \( f \) must be constant.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $ A\subset \mathbb C$ be a closed and countable set. Prove that if the analytic function $ f: \mathbb C\backslash A\longrightarrow \mathbb C$ is bounded, then $ f$ is constant.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Complex Filter Function Metric Finset
open scoped BigOperators Topology

/- Let $ A\subset \mathbb C$ be a closed and countable set. Prove that if the analytic function $ f: \mathbb C\backslash A\longrightarrow \mathbb C$ is bounded, then $ f$ is constant. -/
theorem calculus_52448 {A : Set ℂ} (hA : IsClosed A) (hA1 : Countable A)
  (f : ℂ → ℂ) (hf : AnalyticOn ℂ f (Set.univ \ A)) 
  (hf1 : ∃ M : ℝ, ∀ x ∈ Set.image f (Set.univ \ A), ‖x‖ ≤ M)
  : ∃ c, ∀ z ∈ Set.univ \ A, f z = c := by

informal_statement:
Suppose $r \geq 2$ is an integer, and let $m_{1}, n_{1}, m_{2}, n_{2}, \cdots, m_{r}, n_{r}$ be $2 r$ integers such that

$$
\left|m_{i} n_{j}-m_{j} n_{i}\right|=1
$$

for any two integers $i$ and $j$ satisfying $1 \leq i<j \leq r$. Determine the maximum possible value of $r$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose $r \geq 2$ is an integer, and let $m_{1}, n_{1}, m_{2}, n_{2}, \cdots, m_{r}, n_{r}$ be $2 r$ integers such that

$$
\left|m_{i} n_{j}-m_{j} n_{i}\right|=1
$$

for any two integers $i$ and $j$ satisfying $1 \leq i < j \leq r$. Determine the maximum possible value of $r$. -/
theorem number_theory_607868:
    IsGreatest {r:ℕ | ∃ (m n: Fin r → ℤ),
      (∀ (i j: Fin r), i < j → |m i * n j - m j * n i| = 1) ∧ r ≥ 2} 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose $r \geq 2$ is an integer, and let $m_{1}, n_{1}, m_{2}, n_{2}, \cdots, m_{r}, n_{r}$ be $2 r$ integers such that

$$
\left|m_{i} n_{j}-m_{j} n_{i}\right|=1
$$

for any two integers $i$ and $j$ satisfying $1 \leq i < j \leq r$. Determine the maximum possible value of $r$. -/
theorem number_theory_607868:
    IsGreatest {r:ℕ | ∃ (m n: Fin r → ℤ),
      (∀ (i j: Fin r), i < j → |m i * n j - m j * n i| = 1) ∧ r ≥ 2} 3 := by

  -- several lemmas:
  -- if |a| = 1, then |ab| = |b|, for any b.
  have lemma_mul_abs_both_sides {a: ℤ} (h: |a| = 1) (b:ℤ):
    |a*b| = |b| := by
    rw [abs_mul, h, one_mul]

  -- |a-b| + |b-c| + |c-a| is even
  have lemma_abs_cycle_add_even {a b c: ℤ}:
    Even (|a-b| + |b-c| + |c-a|) := by
    by_cases hab: b ≤ a
    · nth_rw 1 [abs_of_nonneg (by linarith only [hab])]
      by_cases hbc: c ≤ b
      · nth_rw 1 [abs_of_nonneg (by linarith only [hbc]),
        abs_of_nonpos (by linarith only [hab, hbc])]
        have: a-b + (b-c) + -(c-a) = 2*(a-c) := by ring
        rw [this]
        apply even_two_mul
      · push_neg at hbc
        nth_rw 1 [abs_of_neg (by linarith only [hbc])]
        by_cases hac: a ≤ c
        · rw [abs_of_nonneg (by linarith only [hac])]
          have: a-b + -(b-c) + (c-a) = 2*(c-b) := by ring
          rw [this]
          apply even_two_mul
        · push_neg at hac
          rw [abs_of_neg (by linarith only [hac])]
          have: a-b + -(b-c) + -(c-a) = 2*(a-b) := by ring
          rw [this]
          apply even_two_mul
    · push_neg at hab
      nth_rw 1 [abs_of_neg (by linarith only [hab])]
      by_cases hbc: c ≤ b
      · nth_rw 1 [abs_of_nonneg (by linarith only [hbc])]
        by_cases hac: a ≤ c
        · rw [abs_of_nonneg (by linarith only [hac])]
          have: -(a-b) + (b-c) + (c-a) = 2 * (b-a) := by ring
          rw [this]
          apply even_two_mul
        · push_neg at hac
          rw [abs_of_neg (by linarith only [hac])]
          have: -(a-b) + (b-c) + -(c-a) = 2*(b-c) := by ring
          rw [this]
          apply even_two_mul
      · push_neg at hbc
        nth_rw 1 [abs_of_neg (by linarith only [hbc]),
        abs_of_pos (by linarith only [hab, hbc])]
        have: -(a-b) + -(b-c) + (c-a) = 2*(c-a) := by ring
        rw [this]
        apply even_two_mul

  -- if |a| + |b| + |c| is even, then at least one of them is even
  have lemma_even_choose {a b c:ℤ} (h: Even (|a|+|b|+|c|)):
    Even a ∨ Even b ∨ Even c := by
    by_contra!
    simp only [Int.not_even_iff_odd] at this
    have h1: Even (|a| + |b|) := by
      apply Odd.add_odd
      all_goals simp only [odd_abs, this]
    have h2: Odd (|a|+|b|+|c|) := by
      apply Even.add_odd h1
      simp only [odd_abs, this.right.right]
    absurd h
    exact Int.not_even_iff_odd.mpr h2

  -- if b1,b2 are even, then |a1b1 - a2b2| also even
  have lemma_even_sub_abs {a1 b1 a2 b2: ℤ} (h1: Even b1) (h2: Even b2):
    Even |a1*b1 - a2*b2| := by
    replace h1: Even (a1*b1) := Even.mul_left h1 a1
    replace h2: Even (a2*b2) := Even.mul_left h2 a2
    rw [even_abs]
    exact Even.sub h1 h2


  constructor

  · -- r = 3 holds.
    -- for example, we can take (m,n) = (1,0), (1,1), (0,1).
    simp only [ge_iff_le, exists_and_right, Set.mem_setOf_eq,
    Nat.reduceLeDiff, and_true]
    set m: Fin 3 → ℤ := fun i =>
      match i with
      | 0 => 1
      | 1 => 1
      | 2 => 0
    with m_def

    set n: Fin 3 → ℤ := fun i =>
      match i with
      | 0 => 0
      | 1 => 1
      | 2 => 1
    with n_def

    use m,n
    simp only [m_def, n_def]
    decide

  · simp only [upperBounds, ge_iff_le, exists_and_right, Set.mem_setOf_eq,
    and_imp, forall_exists_index]
    intro r m n h _
    -- suppose on the contrary, r > 3.
    by_contra! r3

    -- since r > 3, m,n has at least 4 elements.
    have r0: 0 < r := by omega
    have r1: 1 < r := by omega
    have r2: 2 < r := by omega


    -- |m0n1 - m1n0| = 1
    have h0 := h ⟨0, r0⟩ ⟨1, r1⟩ (by simp)
    -- multiply |n2| to both sides.
    replace h0 := lemma_mul_abs_both_sides h0 (n ⟨2, r2⟩)
    -- |m1n2 - m2n1| = 1
    have h1 := h ⟨1, r1⟩ ⟨2, r2⟩ (by simp)
    -- multiply |n0| to both sides.
    replace h1 := lemma_mul_abs_both_sides h1 (n ⟨0, r0⟩)
    -- |m2n0 - m0n2| = 1
    have h2 := h ⟨0, r0⟩ ⟨2, r2⟩ (by simp)
    rw [abs_sub_comm] at h2
    -- multiply |n1| to both sides
    replace h2 := lemma_mul_abs_both_sides h2 (n ⟨1, r1⟩)


    -- then |n2|+|n0|+|n1| is even.
    have even1: Even (|n ⟨2, r2⟩| + |n ⟨0, r0⟩|
      + |n ⟨1, r1⟩|) := by
      have h0': (m ⟨0,r0⟩ * n ⟨1, r1⟩ -
        m ⟨1, r1⟩ * n ⟨0, r0⟩) * n ⟨2, r2⟩ =
        m ⟨0, r0⟩ * n ⟨1, r1⟩ * n ⟨2, r2⟩ -
        n ⟨0, r0⟩ * m ⟨1, r1⟩ * n ⟨2, r2⟩ := by ring
      have h1': (m ⟨1, r1⟩ * n ⟨2, r2⟩ -
        m ⟨2, r2⟩ * n ⟨1, r1⟩) * n ⟨0, r0⟩ =
        n ⟨0, r0⟩ * m ⟨1, r1⟩ * n ⟨2, r2⟩ -
        n ⟨0, r0⟩ * n ⟨1, r1⟩ * m ⟨2, r2⟩ := by ring
      have h2': (m ⟨2, r2⟩ * n ⟨0, r0⟩ -
        m ⟨0, r0⟩ * n ⟨2,r2⟩) * n ⟨1, r1⟩ =
        n ⟨0, r0⟩ * n ⟨1, r1⟩ * m ⟨2, r2⟩ -
        m ⟨0, r0⟩ * n ⟨1, r1⟩ * n ⟨2, r2⟩ := by ring
      rw [← h0, ← h1, ← h2, h0', h1', h2']
      apply lemma_abs_cycle_add_even

    -- so one of them is even
    rcases (lemma_even_choose even1) with n2even | n0even | n1even
    · -- for n2 even case, use same method, we show |n0|+|n1|+|n3| is even.
      have: Even (|n ⟨0,r0⟩|+|n ⟨1,r1⟩| + |n ⟨3,r3⟩|) := by
        -- |m1n3 - m3n1| = 1
        have hn0: |m ⟨1,r1⟩ * n ⟨3,r3⟩ - m ⟨3,r3⟩ * n ⟨1,r1⟩| = 1 :=
          h _ _ (by simp)
        -- |m0n3 - m3n0| = 1
        have hn1: |m ⟨0,r0⟩ * n ⟨3,r3⟩ - m ⟨3,r3⟩ * n ⟨0,r0⟩| = 1 :=
          h _ _ (by simp)
        -- |m0n1 - m1n0| = 1
        have hn3: |m ⟨0,r0⟩ * n ⟨1,r1⟩ - m ⟨1,r1⟩ * n ⟨0,r0⟩| = 1 :=
          h _ _ (by simp)
        -- multiply n0,n1,n3 to both sides.
        replace hn0 := lemma_mul_abs_both_sides hn0 (n ⟨0,r0⟩)
        replace hn1 := lemma_mul_abs_both_sides hn1 (n ⟨1,r1⟩)
        replace hn3 := lemma_mul_abs_both_sides hn3 (n ⟨3,r3⟩)
        have hn0': (m ⟨1,r1⟩ * n ⟨3,r3⟩ - m ⟨3,r3⟩ * n ⟨1,r1⟩) * n ⟨0,r0⟩ =
          n ⟨0,r0⟩ * m ⟨1,r1⟩ * n ⟨3,r3⟩ - n ⟨0,r0⟩ * n ⟨1,r1⟩ * m ⟨3,r3⟩ := by ring
        have hn1': (m ⟨0,r0⟩ * n ⟨3,r3⟩ - m ⟨3,r3⟩ * n ⟨0,r0⟩) * n ⟨1,r1⟩ =
          m ⟨0,r0⟩ * n ⟨1,r1⟩ * n ⟨3,r3⟩ - n ⟨0,r0⟩ * n ⟨1,r1⟩ * m ⟨3,r3⟩ := by ring
        rw [hn1', abs_sub_comm] at hn1
        have hn3': (m ⟨0,r0⟩ * n ⟨1,r1⟩ - m ⟨1,r1⟩ * n ⟨0,r0⟩)  * n ⟨3,r3⟩ =
          m ⟨0,r0⟩ * n ⟨1,r1⟩ * n ⟨3,r3⟩ - n ⟨0,r0⟩ * m ⟨1,r1⟩ * n ⟨3,r3⟩ := by ring
        rw [← hn0, ← hn1, ← hn3, hn0', hn3']
        apply lemma_abs_cycle_add_even
      -- one of them is even
      rcases (lemma_even_choose this) with n0even | n1even | n3even
      · -- |m0n2 - m2n0| = 1, cannot be even, contradiction
        replace: |m ⟨0,r0⟩ * n ⟨2,r2⟩ - m ⟨2,r2⟩ * n ⟨0,r0⟩| = 1 := by
          apply h _ _ (by simp)
        replace: Even (1:ℤ) := by
          rw [← this]
          apply lemma_even_sub_abs n2even n0even
        norm_num at this
      · -- |m1n2 - m2n1| = 1, cannot be even, contradiction.
        replace: Even (1:ℤ) := by
          rw [← h ⟨1,r1⟩ ⟨2,r2⟩ (by simp)]
          apply lemma_even_sub_abs n2even n1even
        norm_num at this
      · -- |m2n3 - m3n2| = 1.
        replace: Even (1:ℤ) := by
          rw [← h ⟨2,r2⟩ ⟨3,r3⟩ (by simp)]
          apply lemma_even_sub_abs n3even n2even
        norm_num at this

    · -- given n0 is even, we argue |n1|+|n2|+|n3| is even.
      -- and one of them (say, ni) must be even
      -- contradiction to |m0ni - min0| = 1 is odd.
      sorry
    · -- given n1 is even, we prove |n0|+|n2|+|n3| is even.
      -- and reach contradiction in a similar way.
      sorry

soln_description:
4. The given equation is equivalent to $\sqrt{a^{2}-x \sqrt{x^{2}+a^{2}}}=a-x$. From this, we have the condition $a \geqslant x$, and after squaring the equation, it reduces to $a^{2}-x \sqrt{x^{2}+a^{2}}=a^{2}-2 a x+x^{2}$, i.e., $x \sqrt{x^{2}+a^{2}}=2 a x-x^{2}$. One possibility is $x=0$ (which is a solution whenever the condition $a \geqslant x$, i.e., $a \geqslant 0$, is satisfied); otherwise, after canceling with $x$, we are left with $\sqrt{x^{2}+a^{2}}=2 a-x$, and this, after squaring, with the condition $2 a-x \geqslant 0$, i.e., $a \geqslant \frac{x}{2}$, reduces to $x^{2}+a^{2}=4 a^{2}-4 a x+x^{2}$, i.e., $4 a x=3 a^{2}$. In the case $a=0$, this is always satisfied, i.e., the solutions are all numbers $x$ for which $a \geqslant x$ and $a \geqslant \frac{x}{2}$, i.e., $x \leqslant 0$. Now assume $a \neq 0$. Then from the last equation, we obtain another solution $x=\frac{3 a}{4}$; this is a solution of the original equation if the conditions $a \geqslant x$ and $a \geqslant \frac{x}{2}$, i.e., $a \geqslant \frac{3 a}{4}$ and $a \geqslant \frac{3 a}{8}$, are satisfied, which reduce to $\frac{a}{4} \geqslant 0$ and $\frac{5 a}{8} \geqslant 0$, i.e. (again) $a \geqslant 0$.

Thus, summarizing: for $a=0$ the solution of the equation is the entire interval $x \in(-\infty, 0]$, for $a>0$ the equation has two solutions, $x=0$ and $x=\frac{3 a}{4}$, and for $a<0$ the equation has no solutions.
informal_statement:
4. Depending on the real parameter $a$, solve the equation

$$
x=a-\sqrt{a^{2}-x \sqrt{x^{2}+a^{2}}}
$$

in the set of real numbers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Depending on the real parameter $a$, solve the equation

$$
x=a-\sqrt{a^{2}-x \sqrt{x^{2}+a^{2}}}
$$

in the set of real numbers. -/
theorem algebra_105032 (a : ℝ) :
    {x | (x^2 + a^2 ≥ 0) ∧ ((a^2 - x * Real.sqrt (x^2 + a^2)) ≥ 0) ∧
          x = a - Real.sqrt (a^2 - x * Real.sqrt (x^2 + a^2))} =
    if a = 0 then {x | x ≤ 0} else (if a > 0 then {0, 3*a/4} else ∅) := by

informal_statement: Walter, Agnes, and Holly are making beaded lizards. Walter has 476 green beads and 32 red beads. Agnes has 104 green beads and 16 red beads. Holly has 281 green beads and 80 red beads. They all share their beads so as to make the largest possible number of lizards.  If a beaded lizard requires 94 green beads and 16 red beads, what is the number of green beads left over?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Walter, Agnes, and Holly are making beaded lizards. Walter has 476 green beads and 32 red beads. Agnes has 104 green beads and 16 red beads. Holly has 281 green beads and 80 red beads. They all share their beads so as to make the largest possible number of lizards.  If a beaded lizard requires 94 green beads and 16 red beads, what is the number of green beads left over? -/
theorem number_theory_23082 (total_green total_red count : ℕ)
    (h₀ : total_green = 476 + 104 + 281) (h₁ : total_red = 32 + 16 + 80)
    (h₂ : count = min (total_green / 94) (total_red / 16)) :
    total_green - count * 94 = 109 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_23082 (total_green total_red count : ℕ)
    (h₀ : total_green = 476 + 104 + 281) (h₁ : total_red = 32 + 16 + 80)
    (h₂ : count = min (total_green / 94) (total_red / 16)) :
    total_green - count * 94 = 109 := by
  norm_num [h₀, h₁, h₂] at *
  <;> omega

informal_statement:
Let
\[\sum_{n = 0}^{123456789} \frac{3n^2 + 9n + 7}{(n^2 + 3n + 2)^3} = \frac{a}{b},\]where $a$ and $b$ are relatively prime positive integers.  Find $b - a.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let
\[\sum_{n = 0}^{123456789} \frac{3n^2 + 9n + 7}{(n^2 + 3n + 2)^3} = \frac{a}{b},\]where $a$ and $b$ are relatively prime positive integers.  Find $b - a.$ -/
theorem algebra_20555 {a b : ℕ} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hco : a.Coprime b)
    (hsum : ∑ n ∈ Finset.range 123456790, (3 * n ^ 2 + 9 * n + 7 : ℝ) / (n ^ 2 + 3 * n + 2) ^ 3 = (a : ℝ) / b) :
    b - a = 1 := by

soln_description:
1. **Identify the problem constraints:**
   - We need to find positive integers with more than one digit.
   - All digits must be distinct.
   - The sum of the digits must equal the product of the digits.

2. **Consider 2-digit numbers:**
   - Let the number be \( \overline{ab} \) where \( a \) and \( b \) are distinct digits.
   - The sum of the digits is \( a + b \).
   - The product of the digits is \( ab \).
   - We need \( a + b = ab \).

   Rearrange the equation:
   \[
   ab - a - b = 0 \implies ab - a - b + 1 = 1 \implies (a-1)(b-1) = 1
   \]
   The only integer solutions for \( (a-1)(b-1) = 1 \) are \( (a-1, b-1) = (1, 1) \), which implies \( a = 2 \) and \( b = 2 \). However, \( a \) and \( b \) must be distinct, so there are no 2-digit solutions.

3. **Consider 3-digit numbers:**
   - Let the number be \( \overline{abc} \) where \( a, b, \) and \( c \) are distinct digits.
   - The sum of the digits is \( a + b + c \).
   - The product of the digits is \( abc \).
   - We need \( a + b + c = abc \).

   Check possible combinations:
   - For \( a = 1, b = 2, c = 3 \):
     \[
     1 + 2 + 3 = 6 \quad \text{and} \quad 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 = 6
     \]
     This is a valid solution.

   - Permutations of \( 1, 2, 3 \) are also valid:
     \[
     123, 132, 213, 231, 312, 321
     \]

4. **Consider 4-digit numbers:**
   - Let the number be \( \overline{abcd} \) where \( a, b, c, \) and \( d \) are distinct digits.
   - The sum of the digits is \( a + b + c + d \).
   - The product of the digits is \( abcd \).
   - We need \( a + b + c + d = abcd \).

   By intense casework, it can be shown that no such combinations exist.

5. **Consider 5 or more digit numbers:**
   - For \( n \)-digit numbers, the product of the digits must be at least \( n! \) (factorial of \( n \)).
   - The sum of the digits must be less than or equal to \( 9n \) (since the maximum digit is 9).
   - For \( n \geq 5 \):
     \[
     n! > 9n
     \]
     This inequality holds true for all \( n \geq 5 \), thus no such numbers exist.

Conclusion:
The only valid solutions are the permutations of 123.

The final answer is \( \boxed{ \{123, 132, 213, 231, 312, 321\} } \)
informal_statement: Determine all the positive integers with more than one digit, all distinct, such that the sum of its digits is equal to the product of its digits.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine all the positive integers with more than one digit, all distinct, such that the sum of its digits is equal to the product of its digits.
 -/
theorem number_theory_52453 (n : ℕ):
    {n|n > 0 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).length > 1 ∧ ∀ i j:Fin (Nat.digits 10 n).length, i≠ j ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).get i ≠ (Nat.digits 10 n).get j ∧
    (Nat.digits 10 n).sum = (Nat.digits 10 n).prod} =
    {123,132,213,231,312,321}:= by

soln_description:
Solution. Using the inequalities $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}}$ and $a+b+c \geq 3 \sqrt[3]{a b c}$,

we obtain

$$
3\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{1}{a+b+c}\right) \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{a b c}}
$$

Letting $\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{a b c}}=t$, it is sufficient to show that $t^{3}+1 \geq t^{2}+t$, or $(t-1)^{2}(t+1) \geq 0$, which is evident. . .
informal_statement:
Problem 1. Let $a, b, c$ be strictly positive real numbers. Show that

$$
\frac{1}{a b c}+1 \geq 3\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{1}{a+b+c}\right)
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 1. Let $a, b, c$ be strictly positive real numbers. Show that


$$

\frac{1}{a b c}+1 \geq 3\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{1}{a+b+c}\right)

$$
 -/
theorem inequalities_103505 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    1 / a / b / c + 1 ≥ 3 * (1 / (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2) + 1 / (a + b + c)) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 1. Let $a, b, c$ be strictly positive real numbers. Show that


$$

\frac{1}{a b c}+1 \geq 3\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}+\frac{1}{a+b+c}\right)

$$
 -/
theorem inequalities_103505 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    1 / a / b / c + 1 ≥ 3 * (1 / (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2) + 1 / (a + b + c)) := by
  -- use am-gm ineq for n = 3 on a^2, b^2, c^2 and a, b, c
  have h₁ : ((a * b * c) ^ (1/3:ℝ)) ^ 2 ≤ (a^2 + b^2 + c^2)/3 := by
    have : 0 ≤ (1/3:ℝ) := by norm_num
    have := Real.geom_mean_le_arith_mean3_weighted this this this (show 0 ≤ a^2 by positivity) (show 0 ≤ b^2 by positivity) (show 0 ≤ c^2 by positivity) (by norm_num)
    convert this using 1
    . repeat rw [← Real.rpow_natCast]
      repeat rw [← Real.rpow_mul (by positivity)]
      ring_nf
      repeat rw [Real.mul_rpow (by positivity) (by positivity)]
    . ring
  have h₂ : (a * b * c) ^ (1/3:ℝ) ≤ (a + b + c)/3 := by
    have : 0 ≤ (1/3:ℝ) := by norm_num
    have := Real.geom_mean_le_arith_mean3_weighted this this this (show 0 ≤ a by positivity) (show 0 ≤ b by positivity) (show 0 ≤ c by positivity) (by norm_num)
    convert this using 1
    . repeat rw [Real.mul_rpow (by positivity) (by positivity)]
    . ring
  -- invert the last two inequalities
  have h₃ : 3 / (a^2 + b^2 + c^2) ≤ 1 / ((a * b * c) ^ (1/3:ℝ)) ^ 2 := by
    apply le_of_one_div_le_one_div
    . positivity
    . linarith
  have h₄ : 3 / (a + b + c) ≤ 1 / (a * b * c) ^ (1/3:ℝ) := by
    apply le_of_one_div_le_one_div
    . positivity
    . linarith
  -- prove an auxiliary lemma t^2 + t ≤ t^3 + 1 for nonegative t by factoring it
  have h₅ {t : ℝ} (ht: 0 ≤ t) : t^2 + t ≤ t^3 + 1 := by linarith [show (t - 1)^2 * (t + 1) ≥ 0 by positivity]
  -- now the lemma applied on (1 / (abc)^(1/3)) provides following inequality
  have h₆ : 1 / ((a * b * c) ^ (1/3:ℝ)) ^ 2 + 1 / (a * b * c) ^ (1/3:ℝ) ≤ 1 / (a * b * c) + 1 := by
    convert h₅ (show 0 ≤ 1 / (a * b * c) ^ (1 / 3 : ℝ) by positivity) using 2
    . simp
    . rw [← Real.rpow_natCast]
      rw [Real.div_rpow (by positivity) (by positivity)]
      rw [← Real.rpow_mul (by positivity)]
      simp
  -- the inequalities together show following inequality which is almost target
  have h₇ : 1 / (a * b * c) + 1 ≥ 3 / (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2) + 3 / (a + b + c) := by linarith
  -- show it is target by fixing the terms
  convert h₇ using 1
  . field_simp
  . ring

informal_statement:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive numbers such that $a b+b c+c a=3$. Prove that

$$
\frac{a}{\sqrt{a^{3}+5}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{b^{3}+5}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt{c^{3}+5}} \leq \frac{\sqrt{6}}{2}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
/- Let $a, b, c$ be positive numbers such that $a b+b c+c a=3$. Prove that
$$
\frac{a}{\sqrt{a^{3}+5}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{b^{3}+5}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt{c^{3}+5}} \leq \frac{\sqrt{6}}{2}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_604971 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a * b + b * c + c * a = 3) :
    a / √(a ^ 3 + 5) + b / √(b ^ 3 + 5) + c / √(c ^ 3 + 5) ≤ √6 / 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib
/- Let $a, b, c$ be positive numbers such that $a b+b c+c a=3$. Prove that
$$
\frac{a}{\sqrt{a^{3}+5}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{b^{3}+5}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt{c^{3}+5}} \leq \frac{\sqrt{6}}{2}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_604971 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a * b + b * c + c * a = 3) :
    a / √(a ^ 3 + 5) + b / √(b ^ 3 + 5) + c / √(c ^ 3 + 5) ≤ √6 / 2 := by
        -- Step 1: Rewrite each term using the square root of a fraction
        have h1 : ∀ x : ℝ, x > 0 → x / √(x ^ 3 + 5) = √(2 * x ^ 2 / (2 * (x ^ 3 + 5))):= by
            intro x hx
            field_simp
            ring
        rw [h1 a ha, h1 b hb, h1 c hc]
        clear h1

        -- Step 2: Prove an inequality between denominators using (2x+1)(x-1)^2 ≥ 0
        have h1 : ∀ x : ℝ, x > 0 → 2 * x ^ 2 / (2 * (x ^ 3 + 5)) ≤ 2 * x ^ 2 / (3 * (x ^ 2 + 3)):= by
            intro x hx
            have h1 : 2 * (x ^ 3 + 5) ≥ 3 * (x ^ 2 + 3):= by
                have h1 : (2 * x + 1) * (x - 1) ^ 2 ≥ 0:= by positivity
                linarith
            refine div_le_div_of_nonneg_left (by positivity) (by positivity) h1
        -- Step 3: Apply square root to both sides of the inequality
        replace h1 : ∀ x : ℝ, x > 0 → √(2 * x ^ 2 / (2 * (x ^ 3 + 5))) ≤ √(2 * x ^ 2 / (3 * (x ^ 2 + 3))):= by
            intro x hx
            specialize h1 x hx
            exact Real.sqrt_le_sqrt h1
        have h2:= h1 a ha
        have h3:= h1 b hb
        have h4:= h1 c hc

        -- Step 4: Rewrite denominators using the condition ab + bc + ca = 3
        suffices √(2 * a ^ 2 / (3 * (a ^ 2 + 3))) + √(2 * b ^ 2 / (3 * (b ^ 2 + 3))) + √(2 * c ^ 2 / (3 * (c ^ 2 + 3))) ≤ √6 / 2 by linarith
        clear h1 h2 h3 h4
        rw [show a ^ 2 + 3 = (a + b) * (a + c) by rw [←h] ; linarith]
        rw [show b ^ 2 + 3 = (b + c) * (b + a) by rw [←h] ; linarith]
        rw [show c ^ 2 + 3 = (c + a) * (c + b) by rw [←h] ; linarith]

        -- Step 5: Prove key inequality using AM-GM inequality
        have h1 : ∀ x y z: ℝ, x > 0 → y > 0 → z > 0 → √(2 * x ^ 2 / (3 * ((x + y) * (x + z)))) ≤ √6 / 6 * (x / (x + y) + x / (x + z)):= by
            -- Use AM-GM inequality: √(xy) ≤ (x+y)/2
            have h1 : ∀ x y : ℝ, x > 0 → y > 0 → √(x * y) ≤ (x + y) / 2:= by
                intro x y hx hy
                have h1 : (√x - √y) ^ 2 ≥ 0:= by positivity
                ring_nf at h1
                rw [show √x ^ 2 = x by refine Real.sq_sqrt (by linarith)] at h1
                rw [show √y ^ 2 = y by refine Real.sq_sqrt (by linarith)] at h1
                rw [show √x * √y = √(x * y) by refine Eq.symm (Real.sqrt_mul' x (by linarith))] at h1
                linarith

        -- Step 6: Apply the inequality to each term
            intro x y z hx hy hz
            rw [show 2 * x ^ 2 / (3 * ((x + y) * (x + z))) = 2 / 3 * ((x / (x + y)) * (x / (x + z))) by field_simp ; linarith]
            rw [show √(2 / 3 * ((x / (x + y)) * (x / (x + z)))) = √(2 / 3) * √((x / (x + y)) * (x / (x + z))) by refine Real.sqrt_mul (by linarith) (x / (x + y) * (x / (x + z)))]
            specialize h1 (x / (x + y)) (x / (x + z)) (by positivity) (by positivity)
            rw [show √(2 / 3) = √6 / 3 by field_simp ; rw [show (6 : ℝ) = 2 * 3 by ring] ; rw [show √(2 * 3) = √2 * √3 by refine Real.sqrt_mul' 2 (by linarith)] ; rw [show √2 * √3 * √3 = √2 * (√3 * √3) by ring] ; rw [show √3 * √3 = 3 by norm_num]]
            have g1 : √6 / 3 > 0:= by positivity
            replace h1 : (√6 / 3) * (√(x / (x + y) * (x / (x + z)))) ≤ (√6 / 3) * ((x / (x + y) + x / (x + z)) / 2):= by exact (mul_le_mul_iff_of_pos_left g1).mpr h1
            linarith

        -- Step 7: Apply the inequality to each cyclic permutation
        have h2:= h1 a b c ha hb hc
        have h3:= h1 b c a hb hc ha
        have h4:= h1 c a b hc ha hb

        -- Step 8: Final step - prove that the sum equals √6/2
        suffices √6 / 6 * (a / (a + b) + a / (a + c)) + √6 / 6 * (b / (b + c) + b / (b + a)) + √6 / 6 * (c / (c + a) + c / (c + b)) = √6 / 2 by linarith
        rw [show √6 / 6 * (a / (a + b) + a / (a + c)) + √6 / 6 * (b / (b + c) + b / (b + a)) + √6 / 6 * (c / (c + a) + c / (c + b)) = √6 / 6 * (a / (a + b) + a / (a + c) + b / (b + c) + b / (b + a) + c / (c + a) + c / (c + b)) by ring]
        rw [show a / (a + b) + a / (a + c) + b / (b + c) + b / (b + a) + c / (c + a) + c / (c + b) = 3 by field_simp ; linarith]
        linarith

informal_statement:
Find all pairs of integers $(a, b)$ so that each of the two cubic polynomials

$$
x^{3}+a x+b \text { and } x^{3}+b x+a
$$

has all the roots to be integers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all pairs of integers $(a, b)$ so that each of the two cubic polynomials

$$
x^{3}+a x+b \text { and } x^{3}+b x+a
$$

has all the roots to be integers. -/
theorem algebra_607869 (a b : ℤ) :
    (∀ x : ℝ, x^3 + a * x + b = 0 → ∃ n : ℤ, x = n) ∧
    (∀ x : ℝ, x^3 + b * x + a = 0 → ∃ n : ℤ, x = n) ↔ (a, b) = (0, 0) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Find all pairs of integers $(a, b)$ so that each of the two cubic polynomials

$$
x^{3}+a x+b \text { and } x^{3}+b x+a
$$

has all the roots to be integers. -/
theorem algebra_607869 (a b : ℤ) :
    (∀ x : ℝ, x^3 + a * x + b = 0 → ∃ n : ℤ, x = n) ∧
    (∀ x : ℝ, x^3 + b * x + a = 0 → ∃ n : ℤ, x = n) ↔ (a, b) = (0, 0) := by
  constructor
  · -- Proving the sufficiency (only if direction)
    intro h
    -- Let r₁, r₂, r₃ be integer roots of polynomial x^3 + a*x + b
    -- Let s₁, s₂, s₃ be integer roots of polynomial x^3 + b*x + a
    have vieta1 : ∀ r₁ r₂ r₃ : ℤ, r₁ + r₂ + r₃ = 0 → r₁ * r₂ + r₂ * r₃ + r₃ * r₁ = a →
                  r₁ * r₂ * r₃ = -b := by
      sorry

    have vieta2 : ∀ s₁ s₂ s₃ : ℤ, s₁ + s₂ + s₃ = 0 → s₁ * s₂ + s₂ * s₃ + s₃ * s₁ = b →
                  s₁ * s₂ * s₃ = -a := by
      sorry

    -- Lemma: If all real roots are integers with absolute value ≥ 2, it leads to contradiction
    have lemma1 : ∀ α β γ : ℤ, α + β + γ = 0 → |α| ≥ 2 → |β| ≥ 2 → |γ| ≥ 2 →
                |α * β + β * γ + γ * α| < |α * β * γ| := by
      intro α β γ h_sum h_α h_β h_γ
      -- Since sum is zero, γ = -(α + β)
      have eq1: γ = -(α + β) := by linarith
      rw [eq1]

      -- Algebraic transformation in the lemma proof
